entry.title: Accelerating S/4HANA Success: Why Technical Excellence Alone Is Not Enough
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP S/4HANA transformations are among the most significant initiatives organizations undertake. They involve not only a technical upgrade, but also fundamental changes to business processes, roles, and ways of working.

Yet, despite strong technical execution, many S/4HANA projects fail to deliver expected business value. The reason is often simple: users are not ready.

The Hidden Risk in S/4HANA Programs

Most S/4HANA programs focus heavily on:

  • System conversion or implementation

  • Functional configuration

  • Data migration and testing

  • Go‚Äëlive readiness from a technical perspective

What is frequently underestimated is the human side of transformation:

  • Are users aware of what is changing?

  • Do managers understand their role during the transition?

  • Are business teams prepared to adopt new processes on Day 1?

Without addressing these questions, even a technically flawless system can struggle after go‚Äëlive.

Why Change Management Matters

Organizational Change Management (OCM) plays a critical role in ensuring S/4HANA success by focusing on:

  • Stakeholder alignment across business and IT

  • Clear, role‚Äëbased communication

  • Training aligned with real business scenarios

  • Proactive resistance management

  • Leadership engagement and accountability

When change management is integrated early‚Äîrather than added late‚Äîit significantly improves adoption and long‚Äëterm value realization.

Lessons Learned from Real S/4HANA Programs

Across multiple S/4HANA initiatives, a few consistent lessons emerge:

  • Late involvement of business users increases resistance

  • Generic training does not support real‚Äëworld usage

  • Communication overload creates confusion instead of clarity

  • Adoption issues often appear after go‚Äëlive, not before

Successful programs treat change management as a core workstream, not a support activity.

A Practical Way Forward

To improve outcomes, SAP customers and partners should:

  • Embed change management from project initiation

  • Align communication with project milestones

  • Train users based on business impact, not system features

  • Measure adoption‚Äînot just technical readiness

S/4HANA success is not defined at go‚Äëlive. It is defined by how effectively the business adopts and uses the solution afterward.

Conclusion

SAP S/4HANA transformations are as much about people as they are about technology. Organizations that recognize this early‚Äîand act on it‚Äîare far more likely to achieve sustainable results.

If you are planning or executing an S/4HANA program, investing in structured change management can be the difference between a system that works and a transformation that delivers value.

entry.title: S/4HANA Migration Risk You Shouldn‚Äôt Ignore: SOFFCONT1 & Attachment Integrity
entry.content:
Many SAP ECC and S/4HANA systems carry years of unmanaged attachment data. Tables like SOFFCONT1 and relationships in SRGBTBREL grow silently and become a serious risk during S/4HANA migration.

Common issues seen during cutover:

  • SOFFCONT1 becoming one of the largest HANA tables

  • SYSTEM_NO_ROLL or memory dumps during migration

  • Missing GOS attachments after BP conversion

  • Broken ArchiveLink references post go‚Äëlive

These problems usually surface late‚Äîduring testing or even after production go‚Äëlive‚Äîmaking remediation expensive and risky.

Best practices before migration:

  • Analyze SOFFCONT1 growth and attachment volume early

  • Validate SRGBTBREL and GOS relationships

  • Check ArchiveLink repository consistency

  • Perform read‚Äëonly integrity checks before remediation

Addressing attachment integrity upfront helps:

  • Reduce HANA database size

  • Avoid cutover surprises

  • Ensure business-critical documents remain accessible

Attachment data may look ‚Äútechnical,‚Äù but its impact is very real for finance, compliance, and operations

entry.title: Understanding GOS Attachments in SAP: Tables, Storage, and Reporting Explained
entry.content:
Introduction

Generic Object Services (GOS) allow users to attach documents to SAP business objects such as Purchase Orders, Accounting Documents, and Materials. While attaching files is easy, identifying, reporting, and migrating these attachments is often confusing.

This blog explains how GOS attachments work technically and how consultants can report and manage them efficiently.

1. What Are GOS Attachments?

GOS attachments are files linked to SAP business objects using relationships rather than direct table storage. These attachments can be stored in:

  • SAP database (SOFFCONT1)

  • SAP Content Server

  • External repositories (OpenText, ArchiveLink)

2. Key Tables for GOS Attachments

Table Purpose
SRGBTBRELMain relationship table for GOS attachments
SOOD / SOFMSAPoffice document metadata
SOFFCONT1Attachment content stored in DB
DRADUsed only for DMS, not GOS

üëâ RELTYPE = 'ATTA' indicates an attachment relationship.

3. How Object Keys (INSTID_A) Are Derived

The field INSTID_A stores the object key, for example:

  • FI Document ‚Üí Company Code + Doc Number + Fiscal Year

  • PO ‚Üí Purchase Order Number

  • Material ‚Üí Material Number

Transactions like FB03 or ME23N do not store attachments‚Äîthey only display them.

4. GOS vs DMS vs ArchiveLink

Feature GOS DMS ArchiveLink
StorageDB / Content ServerContent ServerContent Server
MetadataMinimalRichArchive-based
ReportingCustomStandard reportsStandard tools

5. Reporting Best Practices

  • Build custom ABAP reports or CDS views on SRGBTBREL

  • Join with object master tables (BKPF, EKKO, MARA)

  • Add attachment indicator (Yes/No)

  • Avoid transaction-based logic

Conclusion

Understanding how GOS attachments are stored and linked helps in reporting, migration, and S/4HANA readiness. A clear distinction between GOS, DMS, and ArchiveLink is essential for clean system design.

entry.title: Understanding GOS Attachments in SAP: Tables, Storage, and Reporting Best Practices
entry.content:
1. Introduction

Attachments are commonly used in SAP to store invoices, contracts, screenshots, and other supporting documents. Most of these are handled through Generic Object Services (GOS). However, many consultants struggle to identify where these attachments are stored and how to report on them.

This blog focuses on the technical understanding of GOS attachments from an ABAP and Basis perspective.

2. What Are GOS Attachments?

GOS allows users to attach documents to SAP business objects such as:

  • Accounting Documents (FB03)

  • Purchase Orders (ME23N)

  • Sales Orders (VA03)

  • Material Masters (MM03)

‚ö†Ô∏è Important:
Transactions like FB03 or ME23N do NOT store attachments. They only display business objects.

3. Key Table for GOS Attachments ‚Äì SRGBTBREL

The main table used to identify GOS attachments is:

SRGBTBREL

Important fields:

  • TYPEID_A ‚Üí Business Object Type (e.g. BKPF, BUS2012)

  • INSTID_A ‚Üí Object Key (Document number, PO number, etc.)

  • RELTYPE = 'ATTA' ‚Üí Confirms attachment relationship

If a record exists with RELTYPE = ATTA, the object has attachments.

4. Where Is the Actual File Stored?

SRGBTBREL only stores the relationship, not the file itself.

Depending on configuration, files are stored in:

  • SOFFCONT1 ‚Üí SAP Database

  • Content Server

  • OpenText

  • ArchiveLink

This depends on OAC0 / OAC3 configuration.

5. How to Identify Attachments for Different Modules

Examples:

  • FI Document ‚Üí Company Code + Document Number + Fiscal Year

  • Purchase Order ‚Üí EBELN

  • Material ‚Üí MATNR

These values form the INSTID_A.

6. Reporting Strategy (Yes/No Attachments)

There is no standard SAP report for cross-object GOS attachment reporting.

Best approach:

  • Custom ABAP Report or CDS View

  • Start from SRGBTBREL

  • Join with application tables (BKPF, EKKO, MARA)

  • Display:

    • Object Number

    • Object Type

    • Attachment Available (Yes/No)

7. GOS vs DMS vs ArchiveLink

Feature GOS DMS ArchiveLink
User-friendly‚úÖ‚ùå‚ùå
Structured documents‚ùå‚úÖ‚ùå
Long-term archiving‚ùå‚ùå‚úÖ

8. Conclusion

Understanding how GOS attachments work internally helps greatly with:

  • Audits

  • Reporting

  • System migration (ECC ‚Üí S/4HANA)

  • Storage optimization

Hope this blog helps SAP consultants facing similar challenges.
Feel free to comment or share your experience!

entry.title: Understanding GOS Attachments in SAP: Tables, Objects, and Best Practices
entry.content:
Generic Object Services (GOS) play a key role in SAP by allowing users to attach documents, notes, and links to business objects such as Purchase Orders, Accounting Documents, and Material Masters.
However, when it comes to reporting, auditing, or mass analysis of attachments, many SAP consultants struggle to identify where and how these attachments are stored.

This blog provides a practical overview of GOS attachments, commonly used tables, and real-world scenarios. 

What Are GOS Attachments?

GOS (Generic Object Services) allow users to:

  • Attach files (PDF, Excel, etc.)

  • Add notes

  • Create external links

These services are available via the ‚ÄúServices for Object‚Äù button in SAP GUI transactions like:

  • ME23N (Purchase Order)

  • FB03 (Accounting Document)

  • MM03 (Material Master)

Key Tables Used for GOS Attachments

1. SRGBTBREL ‚Äì GOS Relationship Table

This is the most important table for GOS attachments.

Common Fields:

  • RELTYPE ‚Üí ATTA (Attachment), NOTE (Notes)

  • TYPEID_A ‚Üí Business Object Type (e.g. BUS2012, BKPF, BUS1001)

  • INSTID_A ‚Üí Object key (document number, material number, etc.)

Example Use Cases:

  • Purchase Order attachments ‚Üí TYPEID_A = BUS2012

  • Accounting document attachments ‚Üí TYPEID_A = BKPF

  • Material attachments ‚Üí TYPEID_A = BUS1001

2. TOA01 ‚Äì ArchiveLink Attachments

Used when documents are stored via ArchiveLink or a content server.

  • SAP_OBJECT ‚Üí Object type (e.g. BKPF)

  • OBJECT_ID ‚Üí Concatenated key (BUKRS + BELNR + GJAHR)

3. DRAD ‚Äì DMS Attachments

If your system uses Document Management System (DMS):

  • Material attachments are often linked here

  • OBJECT_KEY contains the Material Number

Common Reporting Scenarios

‚úî Find documents with or without attachments

Join:

  • BKPF (or business table)

  • SRGBTBREL using object key
    If no entry exists ‚Üí no attachment

‚úî Count attachments per business object

Group by:

  • TYPEID_A

  • INSTID_A

This is useful for audits and compliance checks.

Important Notes

  • There is no direct link between T-code and attachments

  • Attachments are linked to Business Objects, not transactions

  • One Business Object can be used by multiple transactions

Conclusion

Understanding how GOS attachments are stored helps SAP consultants:

  • Build audit reports

  • Identify missing documents

  • Support migrations to SharePoint or other content servers

Knowing tables like SRGBTBREL, TOA01, and DRAD can save hours of analysis and troubleshooting.

entry.title: Fixing SOFFCONT1 Bloat & Broken Attachments in SAP Using Python (No ABAP, No Downtime)
entry.content:
Introduction

Large SAP systems often struggle with SOFFCONT1 table bloat, broken SRGBTBREL links, and failing GOS / ArchiveLink attachments, especially after system copies, Unicode conversions, or S/4HANA migrations.
These issues increase HANA memory costs and create functional problems for business users.

Common SAP Attachment Problems

Many SAP Basis and functional teams report:

  • SOFFCONT1 in top‚Äë5 tables in DB02

  • SYSTEM_NO_ROLL errors during exports

  • 2‚Äì10 TB of binary data inside HANA

  • Missing GOS attachments after BP conversion

  • ArchiveLink repositories not connecting post‚Äëmigration

These problems are usually data integrity issues, not application bugs.

Why ABAP‚ÄëOnly Fixes Are Not Enough

Traditional ABAP cleanup programs:

  • Run slowly on TB‚Äëscale data

  • Consume dialog/background resources

  • Require transports and system changes

  • Are risky on production systems

For large landscapes, a different approach is needed.

Python‚ÄëPowered Integrity Engineering for SAP

A Python‚Äëbased external processing model allows SAP teams to:

  • Analyze SOFFCONT1, SRGBTBREL, and metadata safely

  • Validate attachment pointers and repository consistency

  • Identify orphaned or duplicated binaries

  • Process TB‚Äëscale data without ABAP changes

  • Run with zero downtime

This approach works across ECC, S/4HANA, and RISE environments.

Typical Results Observed

Projects using this method commonly achieve:

  • 30‚Äì70% reduction in SOFFCONT1 size

  • Significant HANA cost avoidance

  • Restored GOS and ArchiveLink visibility

  • Cleaner migrations and exports

When Should You Act?

Consider an integrity check if:

  • SOFFCONT1 keeps growing every month

  • Attachments disappear after migration

  • Export/import jobs fail due to memory or roll errors

  • HANA costs are increasing without business growth

Conclusion

Attachment integrity is no longer just a housekeeping task‚Äîit directly impacts system stability, migration success, and HANA costs.
Modern SAP landscapes benefit greatly from external, Python‚Äëbased data engineering alongside traditional SAP tools.

entry.title: Re: Deletion of CI_COBL
entry.content:
CI_COBL ZZ* Field Removal (Tested)

We added a ZZ* field to CI_COBL in the customer system for a requirement. Later we realized it was not needed and wanted to remove it. After reading SAP Note 3456968, I thought it should not be deleted. But I tested it in a DEMO system and successfully removed it.

Steps:
1) Check all tables where the ZZ* field is used and make sure there are no values stored. If there are values, clear them first.
2) In SE11, select CI_COBL and click Delete.
3) If CDS activation errors occur (CDS_DS_CCS_PAR, V_COEP_V2_4):
- Activate CDS_DS_CCS_PAR in ADT (Eclipse).
- Run FCO_CDS_VIEW_GENERATE again and use IV_RESET (via debug) to regenerate the views so the ZZ* field is removed.
4) Finally, to resolve the NSDM_E_MSEG error, I deleted the Extend View object (ZCI_MSEG_E) that I had created.
5) Check key objects/tables (ACDOCA, BSEG, V_COEP, MATDOC, MSEG). No errors occurred.

Result:
This worked in the DEMO system, and I plan to apply the same steps in the customer development system.

entry.title: Cannot change Revenue Recognition Key to SPFCSC for Customer Project
entry.content:
Hello,

We are using SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition and would like to activate/use the revenue recognition key SPFCSC for a customer project with a fixed price contract.

However, we are not able to change the Revenue Recognition Key to SPFCSC in our system

Could you please advise:

  1. Under which prerequisites and configuration settings the Revenue Recognition Key can be changed for a project/contract item (e.g., before billing, before revenue recognition run, before any postings, etc.)?

  2. What is the recommended procedure to switch an existing project from another key (e.g., SPFC) to SPFCSC:

    • Is it supported to change the key for an ongoing project?

    • If not supported, should we create a new project/contract item and transfer scope, or reverse/cancel postings first?

  3. Which specific Fiori app(s) and CBC (SSCUI) configuration objects should be checked to enable SPFCSC assignment?

 

Title

Event-Based Revenue Recognition - Projects

 

Fiori ID

F4767 

 

Component

CO-PC-OBJ-EBR

         ÂÅáËÆæÊàëËÆæËÆ°‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï∞ÊçÆËøÅÁßªÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤MIGRATION_USERÔºåÊàëÁªôÂÆÉÂàÜÈÖç‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï∞ÊçÆËøÅÁßªÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïÔºå‰Ω†ËÉΩÁúãÂà∞ÂÆÉËÉΩËÆøÈóÆÊï∞ÊçÆËøÅÁßªÂ∑•ÂÖ∑Áõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®ÔºåÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÊâÄÁ§∫Ôºö

 

Âú®IAMÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫èÈ°µÁ≠æ‰∏ãÔºåÁÇπÂáªÂè≥‰∏äËßíÁöÑÁºñËæëÊåâÈíÆÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ÁúãÂà∞Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™‚ÄúÊ∑ªÂä†‚ÄùÊåâÈíÆÔºö

 

         ÂÅáËÆæÊàëÈúÄË¶ÅÊàëÁöÑËøô‰∏™ËßíËâ≤ÁöÑÁî®Êà∑Âú®ÂØºÂÖ•Êï∞ÊçÆ‰πãÂêéÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Êü•ÁúãÈîÄÂîÆËÆ¢ÂçïÂíåÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÔºå‰ª•È™åËØÅÂØºÂÖ•ÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÊòØÂê¶Ê≠£Á°Æ„ÄÇÊàëÂèØ‰ª•ÁÇπÂáªÊ∑ªÂä†ÊåâÈíÆÔºåÊü•ÊâæÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑIAMÂ∫îÁî®Âπ∂Ê∑ªÂä†Â¶Ç‰∏ãÔºö

 

         ‰Ω†ËÉΩÁúãÂà∞ÔºåÊàëÁõ¥Êé•Ê∑ªÂä†‰∫Ü‚ÄúÊòæÁ§∫ÈîÄÂîÆËÆ¢Âçï‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÊòæÁ§∫ÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢Âçï‚ÄùÁöÑÊùÉÈôêÔºåÂàÜÈÖçÁ±ªÂûã‰∏∫‚ÄúÁõ¥Êé•‚ÄùÔºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØÊàëÁõ¥Êé•Ê∑ªÂä†ÁöÑÊùÉÈôêÔºåËÄå‰∏çÊòØÈÄöËøá‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïÂàÜÈÖçËÄåÂæó„ÄÇÊúâ‰∫ÜËøôÁßçÊñπÂºèÔºåÂØπ‰∫éÊàë‰ª¨ÈúÄË¶ÅÈÖçÁΩÆÈùûÂ∏∏‰∏™ÊÄßÂåñÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤Â∞Ü‰ºöÊõ¥Âä†Êñπ‰æø„ÄÇ

 

         ‰ª•‰∏äÊòØÂÖ≥‰∫éSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602ÁâàÊú¨Ë∑®ÊäÄÊúØËØùÈ¢òÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∫õÈáçË¶ÅÂàÜ‰∫´ÔºåÂ∏åÊúõÂØπ‰Ω†ÁöÑÊó•Â∏∏‰ΩøÁî®ÊúâÊâÄÂ∏ÆÂä©„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†Êúâ‰ªª‰ΩïÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÊ¨¢ËøéÁïôË®ÄÊàñËÄÖÁßÅ‰ø°ËÅîÁ≥ªÔºÅ

entry.title: SAP Cloud ERP (S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)¬†2602‰∫ÆÁÇπÂâçÁûª‚Äî‚ÄîAIÂàõÊñ∞ÔºàAI InnovationÔºâ
entry.content:
SAP Cloud ERP 2602 ÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑÂèëÂ∏ÉÔºåÁªßÁª≠Ë∑µË°å SAP ÁöÑÊ†∏ÂøÉÊâøËØ∫ÔºöÂ∞ÜÊô∫ËÉΩÁ≤æÂáÜÂµåÂÖ•ÂÖ≥ÈîÆ‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ã„ÄÇ

2602 ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠Ëøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•Âº∫Âåñ‰∫ÜÂµåÂÖ•ÂºèAIÂú®ÂÖ≥ÈîÆ‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ã‰∏≠ÁöÑÂºÄÁÆ±Âç≥Áî®ËÉΩÂäõÔºåÊòæËëóÊãìÂ±ï‰∫ÜJouleÂú®Êõ¥Â§ö‰∏öÂä°Âú∫ÊôØ‰∏≠ÁöÑËá™ÁÑ∂‰∫§‰∫íÊîØÊåÅ„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰πüÊ≠£ÂºèÂºÄÂêØ‰∫ÜÊñ∞‰∏Ä‰ª£‰ª£ÁêÜÂºèAIÂäüËÉΩÁöÑBetaÊµãËØïÔºåSAP Cloud ERP ÁöÑÊô∫ËÉΩËÉΩÂäõËøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•ÊºîËøõÔºåÂëàÁé∞Âá∫Êõ¥Âº∫ÁöÑÊÉÖÂ¢ÉÊÑüÁü•„ÄÅ‰ªªÂä°ÂÖ≥ËÅî‰∏é‰∏öÂä°ÂØºÂêëÊÄß„ÄÇ

Êú¨ÁØáÂçöÂÆ¢Â∞Ü‰∏∫ÊÇ®ËØ¶Ëß£ 2602 ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠ÁöÑÂÖ≥ÈîÆ AI ÂàõÊñ∞ÔºåÂπ∂ËÅöÁÑ¶‰∫éÂÖ∂Âú®Áî®Êà∑‰ΩìÈ™å„ÄÅË¥¢Âä°„ÄÅÈîÄÂîÆ„ÄÅÂà∂ÈÄ†‰∏éÈááË¥≠Á≠âÊ†∏ÂøÉ‰∏öÂä°È¢ÜÂüüÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ

ÂÖ≥‰∫éÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂú®SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition‰∏≠ÊøÄÊ¥ªSAP Business AIÂäüËÉΩÔºåËØ∑ÂèÇÁúã‰ª•‰∏ãSAP noteÔºö3651017 - Âú® SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ‰∏≠ÊøÄÊ¥ª SAP Business AI ÂäüËÉΩ - SAP for Me

‰∏ªÊï∞ÊçÆÂø´ÈÄüÊü•ËØ¢ (Joule for Master Data)Ôºö

ÁªßÊàêÊú¨‰∏≠ÂøÉ„ÄÅÈõÜÂõ¢Ë¥¢Âä°Êä•Ë°®„ÄÅ‰∏ì‰∏öÊúçÂä°È°πÁõÆÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå‰πãÂêéÔºå2602ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠ÔºåÂú®ÂÖ¨Âè∏Ëé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÔºàCompany ProfitabilityÔºâ„ÄÅ‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÔºàProduct ProfitabilityÔºâÂèä‰ø°Ë¥∑È¢ùÂ∫¶ÂàÜÊûêÔºàCredit Line AnalysisÔºâÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå‰∏≠ÈõÜÊàê‰∫ÜÈ¢ÑÂÆö‰πâÁöÑ AI ËæÖÂä©‰∏öÂä°ËßÅËß£Ôºà‰πüÁß∞‰∏∫‚ÄúÂø´ÈÄüÊìç‰Ωú Quick Action‚ÄùÔºâÔºåÂ∏ÆÂä©Áî®Êà∑Âø´ÈÄüÂàÜÊûêÂíåÈ™åËØÅÂ§öÁª¥Êï∞ÊçÆ„ÄÇ

  • ÂÖ¨Âè∏Ëé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (Company Profitability Review Booklet)Ôºö

ËØ•Â∫îÁî®ÊîØÊåÅÈîÄÂîÆ‰ºöËÆ°ÂàÜÊûê‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊàñÂ§ö‰∏™ÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõ„ÄÇÈÄöËøá‚Äú‰∏öÂä°ËßÅËß£‚ÄùÂäüËÉΩÊîØÊåÅÂπ∂ÊéíÊòæÁ§∫Â§ö‰∏™ÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑËæπÈôÖË¥°ÁåÆ„ÄÇ‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåÊÄªÁªìÊú¨Ë¥¢Âπ¥ÁöÑËæπÈôÖË¥°ÁåÆÔºåÊÄªÁªìÊúÄ‰Ω≥ÂíåÊúÄÂ∑Æ‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑÁ≠âÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇ

  • ‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (Product Profitability Review Booklet)Ôºö

ËØ•Â∫îÁî®‰∏ªË¶ÅÈù¢ÂêëÈîÄÂîÆ‰ºöËÆ°ÔºåÁî®‰∫éÈÄöËøá‚ÄúËæπÈôÖÊ¶ÇËßà‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÈîÄË¥ßÊàêÊú¨ (COGS) ÊòéÁªÜ‚ÄùÈ°µÈù¢ÂàÜÊûê‰∫ßÂìÅÂà©Ê∂¶„ÄÇÂà©Áî® AI ÈíàÂØπ‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÁöÑÊúüÈó¥ÂØπÊØî (Period-over-Period) ÁîüÊàêË¥¢Âä°‰∏öÂä°ËßÅËß£ÔºåÊèê‰æõËæπÈôÖÂ¢ûÁõäÊúÄÈ´ò/ÊúÄ‰ΩéÁöÑÂâç5‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÂèä‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑÂàÜÊûêÔºåÊîØÊåÅÊõ¥ÊòéÊô∫ÁöÑÂÜ≥Á≠ñ„ÄÇ

  • ‰ø°Ë¥∑È¢ùÂ∫¶ÂàÜÊûêÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (Credit Line Analysis - Review Booklet)Ôºö

2602Â∞ÜÁªèÂÖ∏ÁöÑ‰ø°Ë¥∑È¢ùÂ∫¶ÂàÜÊûêÂäüËÉΩËøÅÁßªÂà∞‰∫ÜÊñ∞ÁöÑÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜåÊ°ÜÊû∂‰∏≠„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂AI ÂäüËÉΩÂèØ‰ª•‰∏∫ÊâãÂÜå‰∏≠ÁöÑÊØè‰∏™È°µÁ≠æÁîüÊàêÂ§ö‰∏™ AI ËæÖÂä©ÁöÑÊ¶ÇËßàÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºöÈ¢ùÂ∫¶‰∏éÈáëÈ¢ùÁõëÊéßÔºå‰∫§ÊòìÊéíÂêçËØÜÂà´Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®ÁéáÂàÜÊûêÁ≠â„ÄÇ

 

‰ºöËÆ°Â∫îËÆ°Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ª£ÁêÜ (Accounting Accruals Agent)BetaÁâàÊú¨Ôºö

ËØ•‰ª£ÁêÜËÉΩÂ§üÈÄöËøáËØÜÂà´Êó•Â∏∏Èì∂Ë°åÂØπË¥¶Âçï‰∏≠ÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÔºåËá™Âä®ÂèëÁé∞ÊΩúÂú®ÁöÑËµÑÈáëÁü≠Áº∫ÊàñÁõà‰ΩôÔºåÂπ∂Êèê‰æõÂèØÊìç‰ΩúÁöÑËΩ¨Ë¥¶Âª∫ËÆÆÂíåÊèêÊ°àÔºå‰ªéËÄåÊèêÈ´òÂà©ÊÅØÊî∂ÁõäÂπ∂‰ºòÂåñÁé∞ÈáëÊµÅ„ÄÇ

Áîü‰∫ß‰ºöËÆ° AI ËæÖÂä©ÈîôËØØËß£ÂÜ≥ÔºàAI-Assisted Error Resolution in Production AccountingÔºâÔºö

Áî®Êà∑ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøá Joule ÊòæÁ§∫Âü∫‰∫é‰∫ã‰ª∂ÁöÑÈîôËØØÂπ∂Ëß£ÈáäÂÖ∂Ê†πÊú¨ÂéüÂõ†„ÄÇJoule ËøòËÉΩÊèê‰æõÊñáÊú¨ÂΩ¢ÂºèÁöÑËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÔºåÂπ∂Âú®Â≠òÂú®Â§öÁßçÈÄâÈ°πÊó∂Âª∫ËÆÆÊúÄ‰Ω≥ÊñπÊ°à„ÄÇ

 

ÈîÄÂîÆÁÆ°ÁêÜ (Sales)

Ôºà‰∫ÆÁÇπ3ÔºöÔºâËÆ¢ÂçïÊâøËØ∫ ‚Äì ‰∫ßÂìÅÂèØÁî®ÊÄßÊòæÁ§∫‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰æõÂ∫î‰øùÊä§ÊåáÁ§∫

Âú® SAP Cloud ERPÔºàSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public EditionÔºâ2602 ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠Ôºå‰∫ßÂìÅÂèØÁî®ÊÄßÊòæÁ§∫ÔºàDisplay Product AvailabilityÔºâÂ∫îÁî®Êñ∞Â¢û‰∫Ü‰æõÂ∫î‰øùÊä§ÔºàSupply ProtectionÔºåSUPÔºâ ÂõæÊ†áÔºåÁî®‰∫éÁõ¥ËßÇÊ†áËØÜÂΩìÂâçÊòæÁ§∫ÁöÑÂèØÁî®Êï∞ÈáèÊòØÂê¶Âèó SUP ÈÖçÁΩÆÂΩ±Âìç„ÄÇÂõæÊ†áÁõ¥Êé•ÊòæÁ§∫Âú®‰∫ßÂìÅÂèØÁî®Êï∞ÈáèÊóÅÔºåÂΩìÂú®Ê£ÄÊü•ËåÉÂõ¥ÔºàScope of CheckÔºâÈÖçÁΩÆ‰∏≠ÂêØÁî®‚ÄúÈíàÂØπÁâπÂÆöÂá≠ËØÅÁ±ªÂûãÂêØÁî®‰æõÂ∫î‰øùÊä§‚ÄùÔºå‰∏îÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∑≤ÈÖçÁΩÆ SUP Êó∂ÔºåÊòæÁ§∫ÁöÑÂèØÁî®Êï∞ÈáèÂèØËÉΩ‰∏éÈîÄÂîÆËÆ¢ÂçïÂàõÂª∫Êó∂Áï•ÊúâÂ∑ÆÂºÇÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Á≥ªÁªü‰ºöÊ†πÊçÆ SUP ËßÑÂàôÂØπ‰ºòÂÖàÂÆ¢Êà∑„ÄÅÊ∏†ÈÅìÊàñ‰∏öÂä°Á±ªÂûãËøõË°å‰øùÊä§ËÆ°ÁÆó„ÄÇ

  • ÂÖ∂‰ªñÂ∞öÊú™ÂºÉÁî®ÂíåÂà†Èô§ÁöÑËß£ÈáäÁÆóÊ≥ï
  • ÂàÜÈÖçÁÆóÊ≥ï

ÈÖçÁΩÆ

Âú®ÈÖçÁΩÆÁéØÂ¢É‰∏≠ÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ËøõË°åÁîµÂ≠êÈì∂Ë°åÂØπË¥¶ÂçïÁöÑÂÖ®Â±ÄËÆæÁΩÆ (101024) ÈÖçÁΩÆÊ¥ªÂä®‰∏≠Êü•ÁúãËß£ÈáäÁÆóÊ≥ïÂèäÂÖ∂ËøûÊé•Âà∞ÁöÑËøáË¥¶ËßÑÂàô„ÄÇ

35.SAP Cash Application ÈõÜÊàê

SAP_COM_1018 ÈÄö‰ø°Âú∫ÊôØ (SAP Cash Application Integration) Ëá™ SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 Ëµ∑Â∑≤ÂºÉÁî®„ÄÇ

SAP_COM_1018 ÈÄö‰ø°Âú∫ÊôØ (SAP Cash Application Integration) Âú®2602ÁâàÊú¨Â∑≤Âà†Èô§„ÄÇSAP_COM_0650 ÈÄö‰ø°Âú∫ÊôØÔºàÂÖ∑ÊúâÁõ∏ÂêåÂêçÁß∞ SAP Cash Application ÈõÜÊàêÔºâÊòØ SAP_COM_1018 ÈÄö‰ø°Âú∫ÊôØÁöÑÂêéÁªß„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨Âª∫ËÆÆÊÇ®Â∞ΩÂø´ÂàáÊç¢Âà∞ÂêéÁªßÈÄö‰ø°Âú∫ÊôØ (SAP_COM_0650)„ÄÇ

 

„ÄêÂêéÁª≠Â∫îÁî®È°ªÁü•„Äë

36.Êó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂàÜÊûêÂô®ÔºàÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨Ôºâ

ÈÄöËøáÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨Â∫îÁî®ÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ÂàÜÊûêÂú®ÊâÄÈÄâÊúüÈó¥ÂÜÖËøáË¥¶ÁöÑÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩï„ÄÇÂÆÉ‰ΩøÁî®Â§öÁª¥ÂàÜÊûêÊ°ÜÊû∂ÂàÜÊûêÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩï„ÄÇÂÆÉËøòÊ∑ªÂä†‰∫ÜÊñ∞ÁöÑÊ¥æÁîüÈÄªËæë‰ª•‰æø‰∫éÁî®Êà∑ÈÄâÊã©„ÄÇ

ÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ÂàÜÊûêÂú®ËøáË¥¶Êó•ÊúüËøáË¥¶ÁöÑÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩï„ÄÇÈªòËÆ§ÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåËøáË¥¶Êó•Êúü‰∏∫‰∏ä‰∏™Êúà„ÄÇÂÆÉÊèê‰æõÊÄªË¥¶ÁßëÁõÆ‰∏≠ÊâÄÈÄâÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÁöÑÊ±áÊÄªÈáëÈ¢ùÊ¶ÇËßà„ÄÇÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•Êåâ‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÊä¨Â§¥Â≠óÊÆµËøõË°åÂàÜÁªÑÔºöÂàÜÁ±ªË¥¶„ÄÅÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÅÊÄªË¥¶ÁßëÁõÆ„ÄÅÂ§áÈÄâÊÄªË¥¶ÁßëÁõÆ„ÄÅÂàÜÁ±ªË¥¶‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶„ÄÅ‰ºöËÆ°ÊúüÈó¥„ÄÅËøáË¥¶Êó•Êúü„ÄÅË¥¢Âä°‰∫§ÊòìÁ±ªÂûã„ÄÅÂÖ≥ÈîÆÊó•ÊúüÂíåÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩï„ÄÇ

ËØ•Â∫îÁî®‰ΩøÁî®Â§öÁª¥ÂàÜÊûêÊ°ÜÊû∂ÂàÜÊûêÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩï„ÄÇËøôÂ∞ÜÂêØÁî®È´òÁ∫ßÂäüËÉΩÔºå‰æãÂ¶Ç UI5 ÁªÑ‰ª∂ÂíåËÆ°ÁÆóÂ∫¶ÈáèÁöÑÂØπËØùÊ°Ü„ÄÇ

ËØ•Â∫îÁî®Ê∑ªÂä†‰∫ÜÊñ∞ÁöÑÊ¥æÁîüÈÄªËæë‰ª•‰æø‰∫éÁî®Êà∑ÈÄâÊã©„ÄÇÂÆÉ‰ΩøÁî®‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶ÂèòÂºèÊù•ÈôêÂà∂ÂèØÁî®ÁöÑ‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶ÈÄâÊã©„ÄÇÂΩìÁî®Êà∑ÈÄâÊã©ÂØºËá¥Â§ö‰∏™‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶ÂèòÂºèÊó∂ÔºåÂ∞ÜÊòæÁ§∫Ë≠¶ÂëäÊ∂àÊÅØ„ÄÇ

37.‚ÄúÁÆ°ÁêÜÂõ∫ÂÆöËµÑ‰∫ß‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®ÁöÑÂêéÁªß

ËØ∑ÂèÇÁÖß ‰ªéÊóßÂ∫îÁî®ÁâàÊú¨ (F3425) ËøáÊ∏°Âà∞Êñ∞Â∫îÁî®ÁâàÊú¨ (F3425A) | SAP Help Portal

38.‚ÄúÁÆ°ÁêÜÂéÜÂè≤ËµÑ‰∫ß‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®ÁöÑÂêéÁªß

ËØ∑ÂèÇÁÖß ‰ªéÊóßÂ∫îÁî®ÁâàÊú¨ (F7280) ËΩ¨Êç¢Âà∞Êñ∞Â∫îÁî®ÁâàÊú¨ (F7280A)

„ÄêÊùÉÈôêÂèòÂä®„Äë

39.ÁÆ°ÁêÜÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÁöÑÊùÉÈôê - Êñ∞ÁâàÊú¨Â∫îÁî®ÊùÉÈôêÂèòÂºè

ËÆøÈóÆ ÁÆ°ÁêÜÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩï - Êñ∞ÁâàÊú¨ (F0717A_TRAN) Â∫îÁî®ÊùÉÈôêÂèòÂºèÊâÄÈúÄÁöÑÊùÉÈôêÂ∑≤Êõ¥ÊîπÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÊõ¥Êñ∞ÊÇ®ÁöÑÁî®Êà∑

Ë¶Å‰ΩøÁî®Êà∑ËÉΩÂ§üËÆøÈóÆÊ≠§Â∫îÁî®ÔºåÈúÄË¶Å‰∏∫ÂÖ∂‰∏öÂä°Áî®Êà∑ÂàÜÈÖç‰ª•‰∏ã‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïÔºö

  • ÊÄªË¥¶ - Á∫≥Á®éÁî≥Êä• (SAP_FN_BC_GL_TX_DCL_PC) 
  • ÊÄªË¥¶ - Êó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂ§ÑÁêÜ (SAP_FIN_BC_JL_JE_PROC_PC)

‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïÂøÖÈ°ªÂàÜÈÖç‰∏∫ÊÄªË¥¶ - Á®éÂä°Áî≥Êä•‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïÁöÑÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÊÄß„ÄÇ

‰πãÂâçÔºåÁÆ°ÁêÜÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩï - Êñ∞ÁâàÊú¨ (F0717A_TRAN) ÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®ÊùÉÈôêÂèòÂºèÂ∑≤ÂàÜÈÖçÂà∞ÊÄªË¥¶ - Á®éÂä°Áî≥Êä•‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩï„ÄÇÊ≠§Â∫îÁî®ÊùÉÈôêÂèòÂºèÂ∞ÜÂú®Êú™Êù•ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠‰ªéÊ≠§‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩï‰∏≠ÁßªÈô§„ÄÇ

ËØ∑Áõ∏Â∫îÂú∞Êõ¥Êñ∞ÊÇ®ÁöÑÁî®Êà∑ÊùÉÈôê„ÄÇ‰ΩøÁî®ÊòæÁ§∫ IAM Â∫îÁî®Â∫îÁî®Ê£ÄÊü•ÂäüËÉΩ‰∏äÊâÄÈúÄÁöÑÈôÑÂä† IAM Â∫îÁî®

40.‚ÄúÈáçÊñ∞ÂàÜÁªÑÂ∫îÊî∂Ë¥¶Ê¨æ/Â∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æ‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®ÁöÑÊùÉÈôê - ‰ΩøÁî®Á©∫‚ÄúÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†Å‚ÄùÂ≠óÊÆµÈôêÂà∂ËøáË¥¶ÊùÉÈôê

‰ªéÊú¨ÁâàÊú¨ÂºÄÂßãÔºåÂú®ÈáçÁªÑÂ∫îÊî∂Ë¥¶Ê¨æ/Â∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æÂ∫îÁî® (FAGLF101) ‰∏≠ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊ≤°ÊúâËøáË¥¶Âà∞ÊâÄÊúâÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÊùÉÈôêÔºåÂàôÊó†Ê≥ïÂÜçÂ∞ÜÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÂ≠óÊÆµÁïôÁ©∫‰ª•ËøáË¥¶Âà∞ÊâÄÊúâÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÇÂøÖÈ°ªÂ∞ÜËøáË¥¶Âà∞ÊØè‰∏™ÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÁöÑÂÜôÂÖ•ËÆøÈóÆÊùÉÈôêÂàÜÈÖçÁªôÁî®Êà∑ËßíËâ≤„ÄÇ

Âú®Ê≠§ÁâàÊú¨‰πãÂâçÔºåÁî®Êà∑ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÂ∞Ü ÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†Å Â≠óÊÆµÁïôÁ©∫ÔºåÊó†ÈôêÂà∂Âú∞ËøáË¥¶Âà∞ÊØè‰∏™ÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûúË¶ÅÈÄöËøáÂ∞ÜÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÂ≠óÊÆµÁïôÁ©∫Êù•ËøáË¥¶ÊâÄÊúâÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåÂàôÂøÖÈ°ªÊ≠£Á°ÆÈÖçÁΩÆÂàÜÈÖçÁªôÁî®Êà∑ÁöÑËßíËâ≤

ÊùÉÈôê

Ë¶Å‰ΩøÁî®Êà∑ËÉΩÂ§ü‰ΩøÁî®ÈáçÊñ∞ÂàÜÁªÑÂ∫îÊî∂Ë¥¶Ê¨æ/Â∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æÂ∫îÁî® (FAGLF101)ÔºåÈúÄË¶Å‰∏∫ÂÖ∂‰∏öÂä°Áî®Êà∑ÂàÜÈÖç‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖ∑Êúâ SAP_BR_GL_ACCOUNTANT ÊÄªË¥¶‰ºöËÆ°ËßíËâ≤‰∏≠ÊâÄÂê´ÊùÉÈôêÁöÑËßíËâ≤„ÄÇ

 ÈÖçÁΩÆ

Ë¶Å‰ΩøÁî®Êà∑ËÉΩÂ§üËøáË¥¶Âà∞ÊâÄÈúÄÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåËØ∑ÊâßË°å‰ª•‰∏ãÊìç‰ΩúÔºö

1.‰ª•ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂëòË∫´‰ªΩÁôªÂΩï Á≥ªÁªü„ÄÇ

2.ÊêúÁ¥¢‚ÄúÁª¥Êä§‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ

3.Âú®‚ÄúÁª¥Êä§‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÔºåÊêúÁ¥¢ÂåÖÂê´‚ÄúÈáçÁªÑÂ∫îÊî∂Ë¥¶Ê¨æ/Â∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æ‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®ÊùÉÈôêÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤„ÄÇ

4.ÂçïÂáªËßíËâ≤ÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÈÄâÊã©‚ÄúÊòæÁ§∫ÈôêÂà∂‚Äù„ÄÇ

5.Âú®‚ÄúÂàÜÈÖçÁöÑÈôêÂà∂Á±ªÂûã‚ÄùÂàóË°®‰∏≠ÔºåÈÄâÊã©‚ÄúÂ∏∏ËßÑ‚Äù„ÄÇ

6.ËΩ¨Âà∞ÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÂ≠óÊÆµÂπ∂ÊâßË°å‰ª•‰∏ãÊìç‰ΩúÔºö

  • ËæìÂÖ•Â∏åÊúõÁî®Êà∑ËÉΩÂ§üËøáË¥¶Âà∞ÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÂçï‰∏™ÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÂ∏åÊúõÁî®Êà∑ËÉΩÂ§üËøáË¥¶Âà∞ÊâÄÊúâÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåÂàôËæìÂÖ• *Êó†ÈôêÂà∂„ÄÇ

„ÄêÊÄªÁªì„Äë

Ê†πÊçÆ‰∏≠ÂõΩÁî®Êà∑ÁöÑ‰ΩøÁî®Âú∫ÊôØÔºåÂàÜ‰∫´‰∫ÜSAP Cloud ERP (S4HANA Cloud Public Edition)2602ÁâàÊú¨Ë¥¢Âä°ÈáåÁöÑÈÉ®ÂàÜÊñ∞ÂäüËÉΩÔºåÂºÉÁî®Â∫îÁî®È°ªÁü•ÔºåÂêéÁª≠Â∫îÁî®È°ªÁü•ÂíåÊùÉÈôêÂèòÂä®ÔºåËØ∑Â§ßÂÆ∂Ê†πÊçÆÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏öÂä°ÊÉÖÂÜµËøõË°åÂåπÈÖç‰ΩøÁî®ÔºåË∞ÉÊï¥ÊùÉÈôêÔºåËÆ©2602ÂçáÁ∫ßÊõ¥È°∫ÁïÖ„ÄÇ

entry.title: SAP Cloud ERP 2602ÔºàS/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Ôºâ‰∫ÆÁÇπÂâçÁûªÔºöÂàÜÊûêÊä•Ë°®
entry.content:
ÊúÄÊñ∞S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602ÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑÂèëÂ∏ÉÔºå‰∏∫ÂàÜÊûêÂ∏¶Êù•‰∫ÜÂº∫Â§ßÁöÑÂäüËÉΩÂ¢ûÂº∫ÔºåÊó®Âú®ÊèêÂçáÂèØÁî®ÊÄß„ÄÅÁÆÄÂåñÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÁ®ãÂπ∂Êèê‰æõÊõ¥Ê∑±ÂàªÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØü„ÄÇËøô‰∫õÊñ∞ÂäüËÉΩÂØπ‰∫é‰æùËµñÂèäÊó∂ÂáÜÁ°ÆÊï∞ÊçÆÊù•È©±Âä®‰∏öÂä°ÂèëÂ±ïÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ÂàÜÊûê‰∏ìÂÆ∂„ÄÅË¥¢Âä°Áõ∏ÂÖ≥‰∏öÂä°‰∫∫Âëò‰ª•ÂèäÂÜ≥Á≠ñËÄÖÂ∞§‰∏∫ÈáçË¶Å„ÄÇ‰∏ãÈù¢Êàë‰ª¨Â∞ÜÊ∑±ÂÖ•Êé¢ËÆ®Ëøô‰∏™ÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑÈáçË¶ÅÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇ

  • Êñ∞Â∫îÁî®ÔºöÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂàÜÊûêÂô®ÔºàÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨Ôºâ
  • Êñ∞Â∫îÁî®Ôºö ÊàëÁöÑÊ≥®Èáä
  • ËßÜÂõæÊµèËßàÂô®ÂõæÂΩ¢ÂåñÂ±ïÁé∞
  • ÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜåÂ¢ûÂº∫
  • Â§öÁª¥ÂàÜÊûêÂ¢ûÂº∫
  • „ÄêÈáçË¶Å„ÄëCE2602 ÂºÉÁî®ÁöÑCDS ËßÜÂõæ

 

Êñ∞Â∫îÁî®ÔºöÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂàÜÊûêÂô®ÔºàÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨Ôºâ

Ê≠§Ê¨°ÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂ§ß‰∫ÆÁÇπÊòØÂÖ®Êñ∞ÁöÑÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂàÜÊûêÂô®Â∫îÁî®ÔºåÊòØÊóßÁâàÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂàÜÊûêÂô®ÁöÑÂêéÁªßÁâàÊú¨„ÄÇÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨ÁªèËøáÈáçÊñ∞ËÆæËÆ°ÔºåÊ∑±Â∫¶ÈõÜÊàê‰∫ÜÂº∫Â§ßÁöÑÂ§öÁª¥ÂàÜÊûêÔºàMultidimensional AnalysisÔºâÊ°ÜÊû∂Ôºå‰∏∫Ë¥¢Âä°‰∏öÂä°‰∫∫ÂëòÊèê‰æõÂèØ‰∫§‰∫í„ÄÅÂèØËøΩÊ∫Ø„ÄÅÂèØÊé¢Á¥¢ÁöÑÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÊûêÂ∑•‰ΩúÂè∞„ÄÇÂÆÉ‰∏çÂÜçÊòØÈùôÊÄÅÊä•Ë°®ÔºåËÄåÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊîØÊåÅÁÅµÊ¥ªÂàáÁâá„ÄÅÂä®ÊÄÅÂàÜÁªÑ‰∏éÊ∑±ÂÖ•‰∏ãÈíªÁöÑÂàÜÊûêÁéØÂ¢ÉÔºåÊòæËëóÊèêÂçáÂØπÂ§çÊùÇË¥¢Âä°ÂÖ≥Á≥ª‰∏éÂºÇÂ∏∏Ê®°ÂºèÁöÑÂèëÁé∞ËÉΩÂäõ„ÄÇ

‰∫ÆÁÇπÂäüËÉΩÂåÖÂê´Ôºö

    • ‰ªéSDÂºÄÁ•®Âà∞FI-CAÊÄªË¥¶ÔºöÂú®Â∞ÜSDÂºÄÁ•®Âá≠ËØÅ‰º†ËæìÂà∞ÂêàÂêåÂ∫îÊî∂Â∫î‰ªòÔºàFI-CAÔºâÊó∂ÔºåÊ∑ªÂä†Âà∞SDÂºÄÁ•®È°πÁõÆ‰∏≠ÁöÑËá™ÂÆö‰πâÂ≠óÊÆµÂèäÂÖ∂ÂÄºÔºåÁé∞Âú®ÂèØ‰ª•Ëá™Âä®ÁªßÊâøÂà∞FI-CAÂá≠ËØÅÁöÑÊÄªË¥¶Ë°åÈ°πÁõÆ‰∏≠„ÄÇ
    • Èõ∂ÂîÆÁ´ôÁÇπÁª¥Êä§ÔºöÂÖ≥ÈîÆÁî®Êà∑Ê†πÊçÆ‰∏öÂä°ÈúÄÊ±ÇÔºåÂØπ‚ÄúÁª¥Êä§Èõ∂ÂîÆÁ´ôÁÇπ‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®ËøõË°åËá™ÂÆö‰πâÂ≠óÊÆµÊãìÂ±ï„ÄÇÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Â≠óÊÆµÂåÖÊã¨ÔºöÈõ∂ÂîÆÁ´ôÁÇπ (Retail Site - RFM_SITE)„ÄÅÁ´ôÁÇπÂïÜÂìÅÁ±ªÂà´ (Site Merchandise Category - RFM_SITEMERCHANDISECATEGORY)„ÄÅÈõ∂ÂîÆ‰æõÂ∫îÁ´ôÁÇπ (Retail Supplying Site - RFM_SITESUPPLYINGSITE)„ÄÅÁ´ôÁÇπÂïÜÂìÅÁ±ªÂà´‰æõÂ∫îÁ´ôÁÇπ (Site Merchandise Category Supplying Site - RFM_SITEMRCHDSCATSUPPLYINGSITE)„ÄÇÊ≠§Â§ñÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÂú® SAP Business Application Studio ‰∏≠ÂàõÂª∫ SAPUI5 ÈÄÇÈÖçÈ°πÁõÆÊù•Êâ©Â±ïËØ•Â∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫èÁöÑÊ∫ê‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåÂπ∂Â∞ÜÂÖ∂ÈÉ®ÁΩ≤Âà∞ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁ≥ªÁªü‰∏ä„ÄÇ

Ê≠§Â§ñÔºå‰πüÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∫õÊñ∞Â¢û‰∏öÂä°Â¢ûÂº∫ÁÇπ„ÄÇ‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåÂú®2602‰∏≠ÔºåÊñ∞Â¢û‰∫ÜÂÇ¨Ê¨æÈÄöÁü•ÁöÑBAdIÔºåÂÖÅËÆ∏Âú®ËøêË°åÊó∂Â∞ÜÂÆ¢Êà∑ÁâπÂÆöÁöÑÂ≠óÊÆµÂ°´ÂÖÖÂà∞FI-CAÂÇ¨Ê¨æÈÄöÁü•‰∏≠ÔºåËøô‰∫õÂ≠óÊÆµÂèØ‰ª•Áõ¥Êé•Âú®ÊâìÂç∞Ë°®Âçï‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî®„ÄÇ

Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°APPÊõ¥Êñ∞

‚ÄúËá™ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®ÂèëÂ∏É‰∫ÜÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨„ÄÇÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®Ê≠§Â∫îÁî®ÂàõÂª∫ÂåÖÂê´Â≠óÊÆµ„ÄÅËäÇÁÇπÂíåË°å‰∏∫ÁöÑËá™ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°„ÄÇÂü∫‰∫éÊ≠§Á±ªËá™ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°ÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ÁîüÊàê‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂåÖÂê´Êï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìË°®„ÄÅCDS ËßÜÂõæ„ÄÅOData ÊúçÂä°Âíå Fiori Elements Áî®Êà∑ÁïåÈù¢ÔºàUIÔºâÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇËØ•Â∫îÁî®ÁöÑÊóßÁâàÊú¨Âü∫‰∫é BOPF Ê°ÜÊû∂ÁîüÊàêÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫èÔºåËÄåÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨Âàô‰ΩøÁî® RAP Ê°ÜÊû∂„ÄÇËøô‰∏™Êñ∞Â∫îÁî®ÂÖÅËÆ∏ÊÇ®Ê†πÊçÆ Clean Core ÁöÑÂéüÂàôÂºÄÂèë‰∫ëÂ∞±Áª™ÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇ

Êñ∞ÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑAPPÂåÖÂê´Â¶Ç‰∏ãÂá†ÁÇπÂäüËÉΩÔºö

‚Ä¢ ÁîüÊàêÂäüËÉΩÈΩêÂÖ®‰∏îÂåÖÂê´Áî®Êà∑ÁïåÈù¢ÔºàUIÔºâÁöÑ RAP ‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°
‚Ä¢ ‰ΩøÁî®ÂÆû‰ΩìÊìç‰ΩúËØ≠Ë®ÄÔºàEMLÔºâ‰∏∫‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°Ê∑ªÂä†Ë°å‰∏∫
‚Ä¢ Âú®Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°‰πãÈó¥ÂàõÂª∫ÂÖ≥ËÅî‰ª•ÂÆûÁé∞ÈáçÁî®
‚Ä¢ ‰ΩøÁî®ÂèòÊõ¥Âá≠ËØÅË∑üË∏™Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°‰∏≠ÁöÑÊõ¥Êîπ

 

Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâCDSËßÜÂõæÁöÑÈáçË¶ÅÊõ¥Êñ∞

Â¶ÇÊûúÊÇ®ÁöÑËá™ÂÆö‰πâCDSËßÜÂõæÊòØÂü∫‰∫é I_ProjectBillingElement ÂàõÂª∫ÁöÑÔºåËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑèÊú¨Ê¨°ÊúâÈúÄË¶ÅÁ´ãÂç≥Â§ÑÁêÜÁöÑÂÖ≥ÈîÆÊõ¥Êñ∞„ÄÇ‰∏∫ÊèêÂçáÊÄßËÉΩÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∫ïÂ±ÇÁöÑ I_ProjectBillingElement ËßÜÂõæÂ∑≤Â∞Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊóßÁöÑÂÖ≥ËÅî (_WBSElement) ÊõøÊç¢‰∏∫Êñ∞ÁöÑÂÖ≥ËÅî (_EnterpriseProjectElement)„ÄÇ

ÈúÄË¶ÅÊâßË°åÁöÑÊìç‰ΩúÂàÜ‰∏∫‰∏§ÁßçÊÉÖÂÜµÔºö

ÂØπ‰∫éÂÖ≥ÈîÆÁî®Êà∑ÂèØÊãìÂ±ïÊÄßÔºöÊìç‰ΩúÁõ∏ÂØπÁÆÄÂçï„ÄÇÂè™ÈúÄËøõÂÖ• Custom CDS Views Â∫îÁî®ÔºåÊâæÂà∞Â±ÇÁ∫ßÊúÄÈ°∂Á´ØÁöÑÈÇ£‰∏™Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâËßÜÂõæÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÈáçÊñ∞ÂèëÂ∏ÉÂç≥ÂèØ„ÄÇ
ÂØπ‰∫é3SL‰∏≠Âà©Áî®‰∫ÜÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÂèØÊãìÂ±ïÊÄßÔºöÊìç‰ΩúÊõ¥‰∏∫Â§çÊùÇ„ÄÇÈúÄË¶ÅÊâãÂä®‰øÆÊîπËá™ÂÆö‰πâËßÜÂõæÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåÊòæÂºèÂú∞Ê∑ªÂä†Êñ∞ÁöÑ _EnterpriseProjectElement ÂÖ≥ËÅî‰ª•Âèä ProjectElementUUID Â≠óÊÆµ„ÄÇ

ËØ∑Ê≥®ÊÑèÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûú‰∏çËøõË°åÊõ¥Êñ∞ÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∞ÜÊó†Ê≥ïÊ≠£Á°ÆÂ∫îÁî®Êï∞ÊçÆÊùÉÈôêÊéßÂà∂ÔºåÂØºËá¥Áî®Êà∑Ëé∑ÂæóÊó†ÈôêÂà∂ÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆËÆøÈóÆÊùÉÈôêÔºåËøôÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏•ÈáçÁöÑÂÆâÂÖ®ÊºèÊ¥û„ÄÇ

 

‰ª•‰∏äÂ∞±ÊòØÂú®2602ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠ÂèØÊãìÂ±ïÊÄßÁöÑ‰∫ÆÁÇπÊõ¥Êñ∞„ÄÇÊõ¥Â§öËØ¶ÁªÜÂÜÖÂÆπÔºåËØ∑ÂèÇËÄÉÔºöWhat‚Äôs New Viewer

entry.title: SAP Cloud ERP (S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) 2602‰∫ÆÁÇπÂâçÁûª‚Äî‚ÄîÂØªÊ∫êÂíåÈááË¥≠
entry.content:
Êú¨ÁØáÂçöÂÆ¢Â±ïÁ§∫Âú® SAP Cloud ERP (S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) 2602ÂΩì‰∏≠ÂØªÊ∫êÂíåÈááË¥≠ÁâàÂùóÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑÊñ∞ÂäüËÉΩ‰ª•ÂèäÈáçÂ§ßÂèòÂåñÂíåÈ°ªÁü•ÔºåÂ∞Ü‰ºöË¶ÜÁõñ‰ª•‰∏ãËØùÈ¢òÂÜÖÂÆπÔºö

  • ÂØªÊ∫êÂíåÂêàÂêåÁÆ°ÁêÜ
  • ËøêËê•ÈááË¥≠
  • ÂèëÁ•®ÁÆ°ÁêÜ

ÂØªÊ∫êÂíåÂêàÂêåÁÆ°ÁêÜ

Âú® HTML Áâà SAP GUI‰∏≠ÁºñËæëÈááË¥≠‰ø°ÊÅØËÆ∞ÂΩï

 

ÈÄöËøáÁÆ°ÁêÜÈááË¥≠‰ø°ÊÅØËÆ∞ÂΩïÂ∫îÁî®ÔºåÊÇ®Â¶Ç‰ªäÂèØÂú®HTML ÁâàÊú¨ SAP GUIÊåâ‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÊòæÁ§∫ÈááË¥≠‰ø°ÊÅØËÆ∞ÂΩïÂ∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÔºåÊü•ÁúãÊàñÁºñËæëÈááË¥≠‰ø°ÊÅØËÆ∞ÂΩï„ÄÇ

Âú®Ê∏ÖÂçïÈ°µÈù¢ÁöÑÈ´òÁ∫ßÊ†áËØÜÂàó‰∏≠ÔºåÁÇπÂáªËØ•ÂõæÊ†áÂç≥ÂèØÊü•Áúã‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÁöÑÂäüËÉΩÊ∏ÖÂçïÔºõËã•ÈúÄ‰ΩøÁî®Ëøô‰∫õÂäüËÉΩÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∞ÜËá™Âä®Ë∑≥ËΩ¨Ëá≥‰∏äËø∞ HTML Áâà SAP GUIÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇËØ•ÂõæÊ†á‰ªÖÂú®ÈÇ£‰∫õÊõ¥ÈÄÇÂêàÂú®„ÄäÊåâ‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÊòæÁ§∫ÈááË¥≠‰ø°ÊÅØËÆ∞ÂΩï„ÄãÔºàHTML Áâà SAP GUIÔºâ‰∏≠Êü•ÁúãÂíåÁÆ°ÁêÜÁöÑÈááË¥≠‰ø°ÊÅØËÆ∞ÂΩïË°åÈ°πÁõÆ‰∏≠ÊòæÁ§∫„ÄÇ

 

 

 

Â§áÊ≥®Ê†è‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜË°•ÂÖÖ‰ø°ÊÅØ

ÈÄöËøáÁÆ°ÁêÜÈááË¥≠‰ø°ÊÅØËÆ∞ÂΩïÂ∫îÁî®Ôºå‰Ω†ÂèØÂú®Â§áÊ≥®Ê†è‰∏≠‰∏∫‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÂàõÂª∫„ÄÅÁºñËæëÂπ∂ÊòæÁ§∫Ë°•ÂÖÖ‰ø°ÊÅØ„ÄÇ

‰Ω†‰πüÂèØÈÄöËøáÈÖçÁΩÆÂÆö‰πâÂ§çÂà∂ËßÑÂàôÔºàSSCUIÔºö104064ÔºâÔºåÂ∞ÜÂÖ∂‰ªñÂØπË±°ÔºàÂ¶ÇÊä•‰ª∑ËØ∑Ê±Ç„ÄÅÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÔºâ‰∏≠ÁöÑÊñáÊú¨ÂÜÖÂÆπÂºïÁî®Ëá≥ÈááË¥≠‰ø°ÊÅØËÆ∞ÂΩï„ÄÇÊúâÂÖ≥ÈÖçÁΩÆÊ≠•È™§ÁöÑÊõ¥Â§ö‰ø°ÊÅØÔºåËØ∑ÂèÇËßÅÈÖçÁΩÆ‰Ω†ÁöÑËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°à„ÄÇ

 

 

ËøêËê•ÈááË¥≠

ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Áä∂ÊÄÅËØ¶ÊÉÖ‰∏≠ÁöÑÊî∂Ë¥ßÁä∂ÊÄÅ

Êú¨Ê¨°ÁâàÊú¨Êõ¥Êñ∞ÂêéÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØÂú®ÊàëÁöÑÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Â∫îÁî®ÂÜÖÔºå‰∫éÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑ÁöÑÁä∂ÊÄÅËØ¶ÊÉÖ‰∏≠Êü•ÁúãÊî∂Ë¥ßÁöÑÂ§ÑÁêÜ‰∏≠Áä∂ÊÄÅ„ÄÇ

 

 

ÂàõÂª∫ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑ - Â∑≤ÂºÉÁî®

Êú¨Â∫îÁî®Â∑≤ÂºÉÁî®ÔºåÂª∫ËÆÆ‰Ω†Â∞ΩÂø´ÂàáÊç¢Ëá≥Êõø‰ª£Â∫îÁî®ÊàëÁöÑÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑„ÄÇ

ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Êä¨Â§¥ÈôÑ‰ª∂Ëá≥ÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÁöÑ‰º†Ëæì

Êú¨Ê¨°ÁâàÊú¨Êõ¥Êñ∞ÂêéÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØÂú®ÁÆ°ÁêÜÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑ - ‰∏ì‰∏öÁâàÂ∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÔºåÈÄöËøáÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Êä¨Â§¥Â±ÇÁ∫ßÁöÑÈôÑ‰ª∂Èù¢ÊùøÔºåÂ∞ÜÊñáÊ°£ÁÆ°ÁêÜÊúçÂä°ÔºàDMSÔºâ‰Ωú‰∏∫Â§ñÈÉ®ÊñáÊ°£ÔºàÊ†áËØÜÔºöSL1ÔºâÊ∑ªÂä†Ëá≥Á≥ªÁªü„ÄÇËØ•ÂäüËÉΩÂèØÂÆûÁé∞ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Êä¨Â§¥ÈôÑ‰ª∂ÂêëÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÁöÑËá™Âä®‰º†Ëæì

 

 

ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Â∑•‰ΩúÊµÅ‰∏≠ÁöÑÂÆ°Êâπ‰∫∫ÂêçÁß∞Â±ïÁ§∫

Êú¨Ê¨°Êñ∞Â¢ûÂäüËÉΩÂêéÔºåÂú®ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Â∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÁÆ°ÁêÜÂ∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÔºåÈíàÂØπÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Â∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØÊü•Áúã‰∏ã‰∏ÄËÆ°ÂàíÊ≠•È™§‰∏≠ÊâÄÊúâËßíËâ≤ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÂÆûÈôÖÂÆ°Êâπ‰∫∫ÂßìÂêçÔºåÊ∂âÂèäËßíËâ≤ÂåÖÊã¨Â∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÂèëËµ∑‰∫∫ÁöÑÁõ¥Â±û‰∏äÁ∫ß„ÄÅÈÄöËøá BAdI Á°ÆÂÆöÁöÑ‰ª£ÁêÜÂÆ°Êâπ‰∫∫„ÄÅÂèëËµ∑‰∫∫ÁöÑ‰∏ä‰∏äÁ∫ßÂèä‰∏ä‰∏Ä‰ªªÂÆ°Êâπ‰∫∫ÁöÑÁõ¥Â±û‰∏äÁ∫ßÁ≠â„ÄÇ

 

Êî∂Ë¥ßÁ°ÆËÆ§‰∏≠ÁöÑÂ∑≤ÊâπÂáÜÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢Âçï

Êú¨Ê¨°ÁâàÊú¨Êõ¥Êñ∞ÂêéÔºåÂú®Êî∂Ë¥ßÁ°ÆËÆ§Â∫îÁî®‰∏≠Ôºå‰Ω†Â∞Ü‰ªÖËÉΩÊü•ÁúãÁä∂ÊÄÅ‰∏∫Â∑≤ÊâπÂáÜÁöÑÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢Âçï„ÄÇ

‰ª•‰∏ãÁä∂ÊÄÅÁöÑÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÂ∞Ü‰∏çÂÜçÂú®ËØ•Â∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÊòæÁ§∫Ôºö

„ÉªÂÆ°Êâπ‰∏≠

„ÉªÂ§ñÈÉ®ÂÆ°Êâπ‰∏≠

„ÉªÂ∑≤È©≥Âõû

 

‰ªéÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Â§ÑÁêÜÂ∫îÁî®Ë∑≥ËΩ¨Ëá≥ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÈ´òÁ∫ßÁâàÂàõÂª∫ÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÂ∫îÁî®

Êú¨Ê¨°ÁâàÊú¨Êõ¥Êñ∞ÂêéÔºåÂú®ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Â§ÑÁêÜÂ∫îÁî®‰∏≠Ôºå‰∏∫Âê´È´òÁ∫ßÂ≠óÊÆµÁöÑÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑ÔºàPRÔºâÂàõÂª∫ÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÊó∂Ôºå‰Ω†ÂèØÁõ¥Êé•Ë∑≥ËΩ¨Ëá≥È´òÁ∫ßÁâàÂàõÂª∫ÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ

‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºå‰∏∫Â∫ìÂ≠òËΩ¨ÂÇ®Á±ªÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑„ÄÅÈîÄÂîÆËÆ¢ÂçïÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑„ÄÅÊúçÂä°ËÆ¢ÂçïÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Á≠âÁ±ªÂûãÁöÑÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑ÂàõÂª∫ÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÊó∂ÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∞ÜË∑≥ËΩ¨Ëá≥È´òÁ∫ßÁâàÂàõÂª∫ÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÂ∫îÁî®Ôºå‰æõ‰Ω†ÂÆåÊàêÂêéÁª≠Â§ÑÁêÜ„ÄÇ

 

ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑‰∏≠ÁöÑÁâ©ÊñôÈúÄÊ±ÇËÆ°ÂàíÊéßÂà∂Âô®Â≠óÊÆµ

Êú¨Ê¨°ÁâàÊú¨Êõ¥Êñ∞ÂêéÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØÂú®ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Â§ÑÁêÜÂèäÁÆ°ÁêÜÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑- ‰∏ì‰∏öÁâàÂ∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÔºåÊü•ÁúãÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑ÁöÑMRPÊéßÂà∂ÂëòÂ≠óÊÆµ„ÄÇ

 

 

 

 

ÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑Áõ∏ÂÖ≥Â∫îÁî®ÈáçÂëΩÂêç

Â∫îÁî®Êî∂Ë¥ßÁ°ÆËÆ§ - Êñ∞ Â∑≤Ê≠£ÂºèÈáçÂëΩÂêç‰∏∫Êî∂Ë¥ßÁ°ÆËÆ§„ÄÇ

 

Â§ÑÁêÜÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑ - Â∑≤ÂºÉÁî®

 

Êú¨Â∫îÁî®Â∑≤ÂºÉÁî®ÔºåÂπ∂Â∞ÜÂú®ÂêéÁª≠ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠‰ªéSAP Fiori ÂêØÂä®È°µ‰∏ãÊû∂„ÄÇÂª∫ËÆÆ‰Ω†Â∞ΩÂø´ÂàáÊç¢Ëá≥ÂÖ∂Êõø‰ª£Â∫îÁî®Â§ÑÁêÜÈááË¥≠Áî≥ËØ∑„ÄÇ

ÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÁöÑÂêà‰Ωú‰ºô‰º¥ÂäüËÉΩ

entry.content:

ÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÊ®°Êãü

ÈÄöËøáÁÆ°ÁêÜÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÂ∫îÁî®Ôºå‰Ω†ÂèØÂú®Ê∏ÖÂçïÈ°µÈù¢ÁöÑËèúÂçï‰∏≠ÈÄâÊã©Ê®°ÊãüÂäüËÉΩÔºåÂØπÂÆ°ÊâπÊµÅÁ®ãËøõË°åÊ®°ÊãüÊìç‰Ωú„ÄÇ

ËØ•Ê®°ÊãüÂäüËÉΩÂèØÂ∏ÆÂä©‰Ω†È™åËØÅÊåáÂÆöÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÂ∞ÜÂåπÈÖçÂì™‰∏ÄÊù°Â∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÔºåÂêåÊó∂Á°ÆËÆ§ÊòØÂê¶Â∫îÁî®‰∫ÜÊ≠£Á°ÆÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÂêØÂä®Êù°‰ª∂„ÄÇ‰Ω†ÂèØÂÄüÂä©Ê®°ÊãüÁªìÊûúÊ†°È™åÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÁöÑÈÖçÁΩÆÊòØÂê¶Êó†ËØØÔºå‰ªéËÄåÈÅøÂÖçÂõ†Â≠òÂú®Â§öÊù°Â∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÂÆö‰πâËÄåÂèØËÉΩÂØºËá¥ÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÂåπÈÖçÈîôËØØÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ

 

ÂèëÁ•®ÁÆ°ÁêÜ

ÊÄªË¥¶ÁßëÁõÆË°åÈ°πÁõÆÁöÑÁâ©ÊñôÁª¥Êä§

Êú¨Ê¨°Êñ∞Â¢ûÂäüËÉΩÂêéÔºåÈ´òÁ∫ßÁâàÂàõÂª∫‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÂèëÁ•®ÔºàÂ∫îÁî®Ê†áËØÜÔºöMIROÔºâÂèä‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÂèëÁ•®ÁÆ°ÁêÜÔºàÂ∫îÁî®Ê†áËØÜÔºöF0859ÔºâÂ∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÔºåÊñ∞Â¢û‰∫ÜÊÄªË¥¶ÁßëÁõÆË°åÈ°πÁõÆ‰∏ìÁî®ÁöÑÁâ©ÊñôÂ≠óÊÆµ„ÄÇ

ÈÄöËøáËØ•ÂäüËÉΩÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØÂú®‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÂèëÁ•®‰∏≠‰∏∫ÊÄªË¥¶ÁßëÁõÆË°åÈ°πÁõÆÁª¥Êä§Áâ©Êñô‰ø°ÊÅØ„ÄÇ

È¢Ñ‰ªòÊ¨æÊ∏ÖË¥¶

Êú¨ÂäüËÉΩÊîØÊåÅ‰Ω†ÂØπ‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÂèëÁ•®ÁöÑÈ¢Ñ‰ªòÊ¨æÊ∏ÖË¥¶‰ø°ÊÅØÊâßË°åÂΩïÂÖ•„ÄÅÁºñËæë‰∏éÂ±ïÁ§∫Êìç‰Ωú„ÄÇ

Âú®ÁÆ°ÁêÜ‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÂèëÁ•®ÔºàÂ∫îÁî®Ê†áËØÜÔºöF0859ÔºâÂ∫îÁî®ÁöÑÂàõÂª∫‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÂèëÁ•®ËßÜÂõæ‰∏≠ÂàõÂª∫‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÂèëÁ•®Êó∂ÔºåËã•Ê∑ªÂä†ÁöÑÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÂ≠òÂú®È¢Ñ‰ªòÊ¨æÊ∏ÖË¥¶Áõ∏ÂÖ≥ËÆ∞ÂΩïÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∞ÜÂ±ïÁ§∫Êñ∞Â¢ûÁöÑÈ¢Ñ‰ªòÊ¨æÊ∏ÖË¥¶Ê†è‰ΩçÔºõ‰Ω†ÂèØÂú®ËØ•Ê†è‰Ωç‰∏≠ÂΩïÂÖ•Âπ∂ÁºñËæëÊâÄÊúâÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÈ¢Ñ‰ªòÊ¨æÊ∏ÖË¥¶‰ø°ÊÅØ„ÄÇ

Ê≠§Â§ñÔºåÈÄöËøá‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÂèëÁ•®Ê∏ÖÂçïÔºàÂ∫îÁî®Ê†áËØÜÔºöF1060AÔºâÂ∫îÁî®Ôºå‰ª•Â±ïÁ§∫Ê®°ÂºèÊâìÂºÄÂåÖÂê´Â∏¶È¢Ñ‰ªòÊ¨æÊ∏ÖË¥¶‰ø°ÊÅØÂèëÁ•®Ë°åÈ°πÁõÆÁöÑÂèëÁ•®Êó∂ÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂêåÊ†∑‰ºöÂ±ïÁ§∫‰∏äËø∞Êñ∞Â¢ûÊ†è‰ΩçÔºå‰∏îËØ•Ê†è‰Ωç‰∏≠Â∞ÜÂ±ïÁ§∫ÊâÄÊúâ‰∏éÈ¢Ñ‰ªòÊ¨æÊ∏ÖË¥¶Áõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑ‰ø°ÊÅØ„ÄÇ

entry.title: SAP Cloud ERP (S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) 2602 ‰∫ÆÁÇπÂâçÁûªÔºö‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå
entry.content:
ÂÜÖÂÆπÊëòË¶Å

‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∞ÜÊàê‰∏∫ÂåÖÂê´Áîü‰∫ßÂ∑ÆÂºÇÁöÑ‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõ (W0182) ÁöÑÁªß‰ªªÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∫îÁî®‰∏ªË¶ÅÁî®‰∫éÊîØÊåÅÈîÄÂîÆ‰ºöËÆ°Âü∫‰∫éÂçï‰∏Ä‰∫ßÂìÅÊàñËÄÖ‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑËøõË°åÂà©Ê∂¶ÂàÜÊûê„ÄÇÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜåÂ∞ÜÊòØSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Á≥ªÁªü‰∏ã‰∏Ä‰ª£ÊôÆÈÅç‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑÂàÜÊûêÊä•Ë°®Ê†ºÂºèÔºåÂª∫ËÆÆÂ§ßÂÆ∂Êú™Êù•Â∞ΩÂø´Â∞ÜÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Êä•Ë°®ÂàáÊç¢Ëá≥ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜåÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ

Âú® 2602 ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠Ôºå‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Êñ∞Â¢û‰∫ÜÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÂäüËÉΩÔºö

  1. ÊØõÂà©Ê¶ÇËßàÈ°µÁ≠æ‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢û‰∫Ü‚ÄúÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØî‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÁõ∏ÂêåÊúüÈó¥‰∏ä‰∏ÄÂπ¥‚ÄùËßÜÂõæÔºõ
  2. Êñ∞Â¢ûÊîØÊåÅÁª¥Â∫¶Â≠óÊÆµ‚ÄúÂèÇËÄÉÂá≠ËØÅÁ±ªÂûã‚ÄùÔºå‚ÄúÂ∫ìÂ≠òËØÑ‰º∞Á±ªÂûã‚ÄùÂíå‚Äú‰∏öÂä°‰∫§ÊòìÁ±ªÂûã‚ÄùÔºõ
  3. Êñ∞Â¢ûÊîØÊåÅÂü∫‰∫é‚ÄúÂäüËÉΩË¥ßÂ∏Å‚ÄùÊòæÁ§∫Êä•Ë°®Êï∞ÊçÆÔºõ
  4. Êñ∞Â¢û‚ÄùÊ≥®Èáä‚ÄùÂäüËÉΩÔºõ
  5. Êñ∞Â¢ûAIËæÖÂä©‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÂäüËÉΩÔºõ
  6. Êñ∞Â¢ûÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÁªÜÂàÜÂèØÊâ©Â±ïCDSËßÜÂõæÔºõ

 

2602ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢ûÂäüËÉΩÁöÑËØ¶ÁªÜ‰ªãÁªç

 

Êñ∞Â¢ûÂàÜÊûêËßÜÂõæ

‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∫îÁî®ÁöÑÊØõÂà©Ê¶ÇËßàÈ°µÁ≠æ‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢û‰∫Ü‚ÄúÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØî‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÁõ∏ÂêåÊúüÈó¥‰∏ä‰∏ÄÂπ¥‚ÄùËßÜÂõæÔºåÁî®‰∫éÊä•ÂëäÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÊØîËæÉÂàÜÊûêÔºåÊîØÊåÅ‰∏ÄÈîÆÂàáÊç¢Êä•Ë°®ÊòæÁ§∫ËßÜÂõæÔºåËäÇÁúÅÊâãÂ∑•Ë∞ÉÊï¥ÊòæÁ§∫ÂèÇÊï∞ÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥„ÄÇ

‚ÄúÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØî‚ÄùËßÜÂõæ (Period Over Period)ÔºöÊä•ÂëäÊúüÈó¥‰∏é‰∏ä‰∏ÄÊúüÈó¥Êï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÊØîËæÉÂàÜÊûêÔºàAIËæÖÂä©‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÂäüËÉΩ‰ªÖÂÜÖÂµå‰∫é‚ÄúÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØî‚ÄùËßÜÂõæÔºâ„ÄÇ

 

‚ÄúÁõ∏ÂêåÊúüÈó¥‰∏ä‰∏ÄÂπ¥‚ÄùËßÜÂõæ (Same Period Last Year)ÔºöÊä•ÂëäÊúüÈó¥‰∏é‰∏äÂπ¥Âêå‰∏ÄÊúüÈó¥ÁöÑÊØîËæÉÂàÜÊûê„ÄÇ

 

Êñ∞Â¢ûÁª¥Â∫¶Â≠óÊÆµ

‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∫îÁî®‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢û‰∫Ü3‰∏™‚ÄúÁª¥Â∫¶‚ÄùÂ≠óÊÆµÔºö‚ÄúÂèÇËÄÉÂá≠ËØÅÁ±ªÂûã‚ÄùÔºå‚ÄúÂ∫ìÂ≠òËØÑ‰º∞Á±ªÂûã‚ÄùÂíå‚Äú‰∏öÂä°‰∫§ÊòìÁ±ªÂûã‚ÄùÔºåÁî®‰∫éÁ≠õÈÄâÂíåÊòæÁ§∫Êä•Ë°®Êï∞ÊçÆ„ÄÇ

 

Êñ∞Â¢ûË¥ßÂ∏ÅÁ±ªÂûã

‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∫îÁî®‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢ûÊîØÊåÅ‚ÄúFC ÂäüËÉΩË¥ßÂ∏Å‚ÄùÁ±ªÂûã„ÄÇÂäüËÉΩË¥ßÂ∏ÅÊòØ‰ºÅ‰∏ö‰∏ªË¶ÅÁªèÊµéÁéØÂ¢ÉÊâÄ‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑË¥ßÂ∏ÅÔºåÂú®SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Á≥ªÁªü‰∏≠Áî®‰∫éÂπ≥Ë°åË¥ßÂ∏ÅËØÑ‰º∞„ÄÇ

 

Êñ∞Â¢ûÊ≥®ÈáäÂäüËÉΩ

ÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜåÁ±ªÂûãÁöÑÊä•Ë°®Â∫îÁî®ÊôÆÈÅçÊîØÊåÅ‚ÄúÊ≥®Èáä‚ÄùÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇÂêéÁª≠ÈáçÊñ∞ÊâìÂºÄÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜåÔºåË∞ÉÊï¥Âà∞ÂéüÊúâÊä•Ë°®ÊòæÁ§∫ÂèÇÊï∞ÊâßË°å‰πãÂêéÔºåÊâìÂºÄ‚ÄúÊ≥®Èáä‚ÄùÈù¢ÊùøÔºå‚ÄúÈ°µÈù¢Ê≥®Èáä‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®Èáä‚ÄùÈÉΩ‰ºöËá™Âä®ÊòæÁ§∫„ÄÇ

‚ÄúÊ≥®Èáä‚ÄùÂäüËÉΩÂàÜ‰∏∫‚ÄúÈ°µÈù¢Ê≥®Èáä‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®Èáä‚Äù‰∏§Á±ªÔºåËØ•ÂäüËÉΩÊîØÊåÅÂØπÊï¥‰∏™Êä•Ë°®È°µÈù¢ÁïôË®ÄÔºå‰πüÊîØÊåÅÂØπÊüê‰∏ÄÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊï∞ÊçÆÊèêÂá∫ÁñëÈóÆÊàñËÄÖÁïôË®ÄÂª∫ËÆÆÂ§çÊ†∏Êï∞ÊçÆÁ≠âÊìç‰ΩúÔºåÁïô‰∏ãÁöÑÊ≥®ÈáäÂèØ‰ª•Áî±ÂÖ∂‰ªñ‰∫∫Ëß£Á≠îÂíåÂõûÂ§çÔºå‰øÉËøõÂíå‰ºòÂåñÂõ¢ÈòüÂçè‰Ωú„ÄÇ‚ÄúÊ≥®Èáä‚ÄùÂäüËÉΩÊîØÊåÅÂêéÁª≠‰øÆÊîπÔºåÊ∑ªÂä†ÂàÜÁ±ªÔºåÁä∂ÊÄÅÂíåÊ†áÁ≠æÁ≠â‰ø°ÊÅØÔºåÊñπ‰æøÂêéÁª≠Ê£ÄÁ¥¢„ÄÇ

È°µÈù¢Ê≥®ÈáäÔºö

 

ÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®ÈáäÔºö

 

Ë¶ÅÊ∑ªÂä†ÊàñËÄÖÊòæÁ§∫Ê≥®ÈáäÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂ∞ÜIAMÂ∫îÁî®‚ÄùÊàëÁöÑÊ≥®Èáä (F8232_TRAN)‚Äù ÂàÜÈÖçÂà∞Áî®Êà∑ÔºåËØ•IAMÂ∫îÁî®ÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩï‚ÄúÂàÜÊûê ‚Äì Ê≥®Èáä (SAP_BW_BC_COMMENT_PC)‚ÄùÔºåËØ•‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤‚ÄúÂëòÂ∑• (SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE)‚Äù„ÄÇ‰ΩøÁî® ‚ÄúÂàÜÊûêÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®Èáä (S_RS_CMT)‚Äú ÈôêÂà∂Á±ªÂûãÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÊåâÊñáÊ°£Â≠òÂÇ®ÂêçÁß∞ÈôêÂà∂ÂØπÂàÜÊûêÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®ÈáäÁöÑËÆøÈóÆ„ÄÇ

Ë¶ÅÊõ¥ÊîπÊàñËÄÖÂà†Èô§Ê≥®ÈáäÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂ∞ÜIAMÂ∫îÁî®‚ÄùÁÆ°ÁêÜÊ≥®Èáä (F8233_TRAN)‚Äù ÂàÜÈÖçÂà∞Áî®Êà∑ÔºåËØ•IAMÂ∫îÁî®ÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩï‚ÄúÂàÜÊûê ‚Äì Ê≥®ÈáäÁÆ°ÁêÜ (SAP_BW_BC_COMMENT_ADM_PC)‚ÄùÔºåËØ•‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤‚ÄúÂàÜÊûê‰∏ìÂÆ∂ (SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST)‚Äù„ÄÇ‰ΩøÁî® ‚ÄúÂàÜÊûêÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®Èáä (S_RS_CMT)‚Äú ÈôêÂà∂Á±ªÂûãÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÊåâÊñáÊ°£Â≠òÂÇ®ÂêçÁß∞ÈôêÂà∂ÂØπÂàÜÊûêÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®ÈáäÁöÑËÆøÈóÆ„ÄÇ

 

Êñ∞Â¢ûAIËæÖÂä©‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÂäüËÉΩ

‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∫îÁî®‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢ûAI ËæÖÂä©‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇÁõÆÂâçSAPÁ≥ªÁªüÂú®‚ÄúÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØî‚ÄùËßÜÂõæ‰∏≠È¢ÑËÆæ‰∫Ü4‰∏™‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÂàÜÊûêÂèÇÊï∞Ôºö

  1. ÊåâÊúÄÂ§ßËæπÈôÖÂà©Ê∂¶ÁöÑÂâç 5 ‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑÔºöÊ†πÊçÆÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØîËßÜÂõæ‰∏≠ÁöÑËæπÈôÖË¥°ÁåÆ II ÔºåÊü•ÊâæÂπ∂Ëß£ÈáäÂà©Ê∂¶Â¢ûÂä†ÊúÄÈ´òÁöÑ‰∫î‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑ„ÄÇ
  2. ÊåâÊúÄÂ§ßËæπÈôÖÂà©Ê∂¶ÁöÑÊúÄÂêé 5 ‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑÔºöÊ†πÊçÆÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØîËßÜÂõæ‰∏≠ÁöÑËæπÈôÖË¥°ÁåÆ II ÔºåÊü•ÊâæÂπ∂Ëß£ÈáäÂà©Ê∂¶Â¢ûÂä†ÊúÄ‰ΩéÁöÑ‰∫î‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑ„ÄÇ
  3. ÊåâÊúÄÂ§ßËæπÈôÖÂà©Ê∂¶ÁöÑÂâç 5 ‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÔºöÊ†πÊçÆÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØîËßÜÂõæ‰∏≠ÁöÑËæπÈôÖË¥°ÁåÆ II ÔºåÊü•ÊâæÂπ∂Ëß£ÈáäÂà©Ê∂¶Â¢ûÂä†ÊúÄÈ´òÁöÑ‰∫î‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅ„ÄÇ
  4. ÊåâÊúÄÂ§ßËæπÈôÖÂà©Ê∂¶ÁöÑÊúÄÂêé 5 ‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÔºöÊ†πÊçÆÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØîËßÜÂõæ‰∏≠ÁöÑËæπÈôÖË¥°ÁåÆ II ÔºåÊü•ÊâæÂπ∂Ëß£ÈáäÂà©Ê∂¶Â¢ûÈïøÊúÄ‰ΩéÁöÑ‰∫î‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅ„ÄÇ

 

Ë¶Å‰ΩøÁî®AI ËæÖÂä©‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÂäüËÉΩÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂ∞ÜIAMÂ∫îÁî®‚ÄùÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8405_TRAN)‚Äù ÂàÜÈÖçÂà∞Áî®Êà∑ÔºåËØ•IAMÂ∫îÁî®ÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩï‚ÄúÂàÜÊûê ‚Äì ÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØü (SAP_BW_BC_RVB_ABI_PC)‚ÄùÔºåËØ•‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤‚ÄúÂëòÂ∑• (SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE)‚Äù„ÄÇ

Êà™Ê≠¢Ëá≥SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 ÁâàÊú¨ÔºåÂêåÊ†∑ÊîØÊåÅAI ËæÖÂä©‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÔºàFinancial Business InsightsÔºâÂäüËÉΩÁöÑÂàÜÊûêÊä•Ë°®Â∫îÁî®ÂåÖÊã¨Ôºå‰ΩÜ‰∏çÈôê‰∫éÔºö

entry.title: Provide access on the Absoft BTP Global account
entry.content:
Could you please guide us on how to obtain the Global Account Administrator role for my S-user?

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Provide access on the Absoft BTP Global account
entry.content:
To add yourself as a BTP Global Account Administrator, you will need to contact an S-user with the Super Administrator role (Under Users & Contacts - SAP for Me). This role allows them to grant the necessary permissions. 
For further details on this process, you can refer to KBA: 2669325 - How to add a user as a SAP Business Technology Platform Global Account Administrator

If you have any questions, please feel free to contact us.

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Automating Attachment Purges in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central
entry.content:
Hi @karenperez,
Great solution ‚Äî really smart use of Integration Center for a no‚Äëcode purge approach in EC core portlets. üëè

On @JulieMcSwain‚Äôs question: this should work if the onboarding attachments end up stored in EC core portlets (e.g., Personal Data or Job Information). If the documents remain in Onboarding or MDF objects, then standard DRTM (Purge MDF Attachments) or ONB‚Äëspecific purge options would still be the right approach.

Thanks for sharing ‚Äî this nicely fills a real DRTM gap for EC core portlets.

entry.title: Re: Understanding GOS Attachments in SAP: Tables, Objects, and Best Practices
entry.content:
Hi @juveria_sap_integrity,
Great practical overview of GOS attachments and the key tables ‚Äî very useful for audits and reporting. üëè

One small addition: in classic GOS, the attachment content itself is often stored in SOFFCONT1 / SOOD (SAPoffice) or via KPro in SDOKCONT1 when using a content server, with SRGBTBREL acting as the relationship layer. Also, programmatically, CL_BINARY_RELATION is very handy for reading and managing these links.

Thanks for sharing ‚Äî this will definitely save consultants a lot of time.

entry.title: Clean Core: Building a Flexible Custom Business Configuration for HTTP Endpoints in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Introduction

This post presents a technique for creating configuration in SAP S/4HANA that fully respects clean‚Äëcore principles, while offering more flexibility than traditional ECC customizing (SM30 or SPRO).
The use case is particularly interesting because it also touches on best practices for connecting SAP S/4HANA to Integration Suite ‚Äî or more generally, to any public API.
However, the primary goal here is to explain how to build a Custom Business Configuration (CBC) ‚Äî the clean‚Äëcore replacement for SPRO entries ‚Äî and, more importantly, how to adapt it so that only selected fields are transport‚Äëcontrolled while others remain editable directly in each environment.
The result is a clean‚Äëcore‚Äëcompliant solution that is more powerful than legacy SPRO customizing.

Use Case

Connections from S/4HANA to external APIs are increasing significantly with SAP‚Äôs ‚ÄúAPI First‚Äù strategy. This is very true on my project: we call Integration Suite, which then calls public APIs while managing authentication and potential transformations.
On S/4HANA on‚Äëpremise or private cloud, the recommended practice is to use destinations (transaction SM59, type G for HTTP).
In public cloud, this would instead be done using Communication Arrangements.
A typical ABAP call looks like:
 
DATA(get_device_auth_destination) =
  cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_destination(
    i_name = 'DESTINATION_NAME' ).

DATA(http_client) =
  cl_web_http_client_manager=>create_by_http_destination(
    i_destination = get_device_auth_destination ).

http_client->get_http_request( )->set_uri_path(
  i_uri_path = '/path/endpoint' ).

DATA(http_response) =
  http_client->execute( i_method = if_web_http_client=>get ).

DATA(response_text) = http_response->get_text( ).
 In this simple example, both the destination and the endpoint path are hard‚Äëcoded.

The Problem

Good practice suggests that:
  • The API endpoint URL should not be stored in the program.
  • Ideally, there should be one dedicated destination per API, allowing:
    • API‚Äëlevel call authorization
    • Authentication configuration (e.g., principal propagation)
    • Timeout settings
    • Emergency deactivation of an API by disabling the destination
In practice, because most APIs go through Integration Suite, we want to avoid creating dozens of destinations.
We therefore use one common destination but still need the ability to override it when necessary.
To achieve this, we create a custom configuration, allowing us to define ‚Äî per flow type:
  • HTTP destination
  • Endpoint path
  • English description
  • Active / inactive flag
Here is the table:
 
@EndUserText.label : 'HTTP endpoint configuration'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #C
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zbct_a_httpendp {
  key client      : abap.clnt not null;
  key flow_id     : zhttp_endpoint_flow_id not null;
  rfc_destination : rfcdest;
  path            : zhttp_endpoint_path;
  is_active       : zhttp_endpoint_is_active;
  description     : zhttp_endpoint_description;
}
The requirement is:
  • Creating a flow ID with its initial settings must be possible only in the reference client.
  • But fields like path and active flag must be editable in all environments.

Creating the Custom Business Configuration

Once the table is created, generating a CBC object is straightforward:
open the ABAP Object Generator and select "Maintenance Object".
This automatically generates RAP objects (Restful ABAP Programming Model).
This is where it gets powerful: we can adjust these objects to control precisely which fields are editable depending on the environment.

Adjusting the Behavior Definition

Open the generated behavior definition (in my case ZBP_I_HTTPENDPOINTCONFIGU_S).
Our goal is:
  • The Edit button must always be enabled.
  • Some fields must be read‚Äëonly outside the reference client:
    • RFC Destination
    • Description
We simply define this logic in the behavior definition.
Next, open the implementation class (ZBP_‚Ä¶) and go to Local Types.
We remove the default "Edit" restrictions and implement our own logic to disable selected fields when the configuration is opened in a non‚Äëreference environment.
This ensures:
  • In production (or any non‚Äëreference client):
    ‚Üí only path and active flag are editable
  • In the reference client:
    ‚Üí everything is editable

Testing the Result

Open the Custom Business Configuration app and select your configuration object.
In a productive environment, you will see the expected restrictions: only the intended fields are editable.
In the reference client, all fields remain modifiable.

entry.title: Re: A 60-Minute Regression Test Plan for Joule in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Excellent and very practical regression checklist for Joule in SuccessFactors üëè

I really like the focus on RBP-aligned outputs, boundary testing (ESS vs MSS), and lightweight, audit‚Äëready evidence. The negative test for restricted users is especially valuable and often overlooked.

This will be very useful for release sign-off and post‚Äëdeployment sanity checks. Thanks for sharing such a clear, reusable framework.

entry.title: Re: How to create an input form for a list-type variable in SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
@UdayMS 
The cause in the point I mentioned in step 1, ‚ÄúCreate a variable to store this data.‚Äù
You have declared a Page variable, but since it has only been declared, its content is still null. You cannot add elements to a null variable.
Therefore, for example, in the Page‚Äôs Page Mounted event, use Set Page Variables to assign a value ‚Äî even an empty string is fine ‚Äî to both variable1 and variable1.items. That will make it work correctly.

entry.title: Infinite loading in rap object page
entry.content: Hello, I made a program for rap odata v4. I can see my list page but when I get into create buttorn or object page, I can't see any elements of object page still stuck in loading page.

entry.title: [SF ONB] How to make fields not required during Review New Hire and required during PDC & MPH?
entry.content: Hello. I'm trying to create a business rule that will make personal info fields like Date of Birth not required during Review New Hire Data but should be required during Personal Data Collection. I'm able to achieve this but it is also affecting the MPH and Add New Employee page.

entry.title: Configuring Multi-Time-Zone Support in SAP SuccessFactors (Single Time Zone Currently Set)
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I was wondering how to configure the time zone settings for an SAP SuccessFactors instance that is currently set to a single time zone, and add support for multiple time zones.

As far as I understand, there‚Äôs no additional setup required‚Äîeach user can simply select their time zone in Job Information. Is that correct? If there are any additional settings I need to configure, could you please let me know?

- The tenant preferred time zone is set to Asia/Tokyo, and we plan to add additional countries such as the United States, China, the United Kingdom, France, and Mexico.

Thanks in advance.

‰∏öÂä°ÈúÄÊ±Ç

Êñ∞ÁöÑËæìÂá∫Ê∏†ÈÅìEXTOMÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÈîÄÂîÆÂá≠ËØÅ‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî®ÔºåËøô‰∏™Ê∏†ÈÅìÂèØ‰ª•ÂèëÈÄÅÊï∞ÊçÆÂú®XMLÊ†ºÂºè‰∏≠Âà∞Â§ñÈÉ®Á≥ªÁªü„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûúÂÆ¢Êà∑‰ΩøÁî®Èô§Adobe Document ServicesÂ§ñÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑Êù•ÁîüÊàêÊâìÂç∞Ë°®ÂçïÔºåÈÇ£‰πàËøô‰∏™Ê∏†ÈÅìÂ∞±ÁâπÂà´ÊúâÁî®„ÄÇ

ÂâçÊèêÈÖçÁΩÆ

Âú®‰ΩøÁî®Êñ∞ÁöÑÊ∏†ÈÅìEXTOMÂâçÔºåÂÆ¢Êà∑ÈúÄË¶ÅÊøÄÊ¥ªÂπ∂‰∏îÈÖçÁΩÆ‰∏öÂä°Âú∫ÊôØ7DJ(Integration of External Output Management Solution)ÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂú®OPD(Output Parameter Determination)‰∏≠Â¢ûÂä†Êñ∞ÁöÑÊ∏†ÈÅìEXTOM„ÄÇ

7. Êñ∞Â¢ûAPIÈÖçÁΩÆÁÇπ

‰∏öÂä°ÈúÄÊ±Ç

ÂØπ‰∫éÈîÄÂîÆËÆ¢ÂçïÔºåÂÆ¢Êà∑ÂèØ‰ª•ÂÆö‰πâÂú®ÈîÄÂîÆÂêàÂêåÈ°πÁöÑËá™Âä®ÂàÜÈÖçÂá∫Áé∞ÈóÆÈ¢òÊó∂ÔºåÁâπÂÆöÁöÑ API Â¶Ç‰ΩïÂÅöÂá∫ÂèçÂ∫î„ÄÇ

ÊÇ®ËøòÂèØ‰ª•ÂÆö‰πâÂΩì OData V4 API ÂØπÊ®°ÊãüÈîÄÂîÆËÆ¢ÂçïÁöÑÂàõÂª∫ÊàñÊõ¥Êñ∞Êìç‰ΩúÈÅáÂà∞ÈîôËØØÊó∂ÔºåËØ• API Â∫îÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂìçÂ∫î„ÄÇ

ÈÖçÁΩÆÁÇπ

1. SSCUIÔºö107106, ‰∏∫ÈîÄÂîÆËÆ¢Âçï‰∏≠È°πÁõÆÁöÑËá™Âä®ÂàÜÈÖçÈóÆÈ¢òÂÆö‰πâAPIÂèçÂ∫î

2. SSCUI: 107246, ËÆæÁΩÆÈîÄÂîÆÂá≠ËØÅÊ®°Êãü API ÁöÑÈîôËØØÂ§ÑÁêÜÊ®°Âºè (OData V4Ôºâ

8. ÂºÄÁ•®ÂÅèÁ¶ªËøáË¥¶Êó•Êúü

‰∏öÂä°ÈúÄÊ±Ç

ËÄÉËôë‰∏Ä‰∏™Â∏∏ËßÅÂú∫ÊôØÔºöÂí®ËØ¢È°æÈóÆÊØèÂë®‰∫îËøõÈ°πÈ°πÁõÆÊúçÂä°ËøáË¥¶Êó∂Èó¥Á°ÆËÆ§Ôºå‰ΩÜÂÆûÈôÖÂºÄÁ•®Âú®Ê¨°Êúà5Êó•ËøõË°å„ÄÇÂΩìÂÖ∂‰∏≠Êüê‰∏™Âë®‰∫îËêΩÂÖ•Êñ∞ÁöÑËøáË¥¶ÊúüÈó¥Êó∂ÔºåÂêàÁêÜÁöÑÂÅöÊ≥ïÊòØ‰ΩøÁî®‰∏äÊúàÊúÄÂêé‰∏ÄÂ§©‰Ωú‰∏∫ËøáË¥¶Êó•ÊúüÔºå‰ΩÜÂ∞ÜÂºÄÁ•®Êó•ÊúüËÆæ‰∏∫Ê¨°Êúà5Êó•„ÄÇËøôÁßçËÆæÁΩÆÁ°Æ‰øùÊàêÊú¨ÔºàÊó∂Èó¥Á°ÆËÆ§ÔºâÂíåÊî∂ÂÖ•ÔºàÂºÄÁ•®ÈáëÈ¢ùÔºâÈÉΩËÉΩÂàÜÈÖçÂà∞Âêå‰∏Ä‰∏™ËøáË¥¶ÊúüÈó¥„ÄÇ Ê≠§Â§ñÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÂºÄÁ•®ÂêéÂá∫Áé∞‰∫âËÆÆÔºåÂèØ‰ª•‰øùÁïôÂéüÂßãÂèëÁ•®ÁöÑÂºÄÁ•®Êó•ÊúüÔºåÂêåÊó∂Â∞ÜËøáË¥¶Êó•ÊúüË∞ÉÊï¥Âà∞ÂΩìÂâçÊúüÈó¥Ôºå‰ªéËÄåÈÅøÂÖçÂºÄÁ•®ÊúüÈó¥ÂíåËøáË¥¶ÊúüÈó¥‰∏çÂåπÈÖçÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ

Á≥ªÁªüÂÆûÁé∞

9. ÁªèÂÖ∏ÂÖ¨Âè∏Èó¥ÂºÄÁ•®Â∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æÂêéÂè∞Â§ÑÁêÜÊ°ÜÊû∂

ÂΩì‰∫§Ë¥ßÂÖ¨Âè∏Â∞ÜÂÖ¨Âè∏Èó¥ÂèëÁ•®Â∫îÊî∂Ë¥¶Ê¨æËøáË¥¶Êó∂ÔºåËæìÂá∫Â§ÑÁêÜ‰ºöËá™Âä®Ëß¶ÂèëÁõ∏Â∫îÂ∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æÂà∞ÈîÄÂîÆÂÖ¨Âè∏Ë¥¶Êà∑ÁöÑËøáË¥¶„ÄÇ‰ªéÈîÄÂîÆÂÖ¨Âè∏ÁöÑËßíÂ∫¶Êù•ÁúãÔºåËøô‰∫õÂ∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æ‰ª£Ë°®‰∫§‰ªòÁªôÂÆ¢Êà∑ÁöÑË¥ßÁâ©ÁöÑ‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÂèëÁ•®„ÄÇ‰∏∫‰∫Ü‰ΩøÊ≠§ËøáË¥¶Êú∫Âà∂ÊåâÈ¢ÑÊúüËøêË°åÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÊâßË°åÁâπÂÆöÁöÑËÆæÁΩÆÊ≠•È™§„ÄÇ

Á≥ªÁªüÁõÆÂâçÊèê‰æõ‰∏§ÁßçÊñπÊ≥ïÂ∞Ü‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖ¨Âè∏Èó¥ÂèëÁ•®ÁöÑÂ∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æËøáË¥¶Âà∞ÈîÄÂîÆÂÖ¨Âè∏ÁöÑË¥¶Êà∑„ÄÇËøô‰∏§ÁßçÊñπÊ≥ïÈÉΩÂú®ÂÖ¨Âè∏Èó¥ÂèëÁ•®ÁöÑËæìÂá∫Â§ÑÁêÜÊúüÈó¥Ëß¶ÂèëÔºö

  • ÊñπÊ≥ï1ÔºàÊé®ËçêËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÔºâÔºöÈÄöËøáÂêéÂè∞Â§ÑÁêÜÊ°ÜÊû∂ÔºàbgPFÔºâÔºå‰ΩøÁî®ËæìÂá∫ÈÄöÈÅìEDI Â¶ÇÊûúÊÇ®ÊòØÈ¶ñÊ¨°ËÆæÁΩÆÂ∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æÁöÑËá™Âä®ËøáË¥¶ÔºåËØ∑‰ΩøÁî®Ê≠§ÊñπÊ≥ï„ÄÇ

    ËØ¶ÁªÜËøáÁ®ãËØ∑ÂèÇËÄÉÔºöAutomatic Posting of Payables to the Selling Company‚Äôs Accounts | SAP Help Portal

  • ÊñπÊ≥ï2ÔºàÂç≥Â∞ÜÂ∫üÂºÉËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÔºâÔºöÈÄöËøáIDocÂ§ÑÁêÜÔºå‰ΩøÁî®ËæìÂá∫ÈÄöÈÅìIDOC Âú®‰ª•ÂâçÁöÑÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠ÔºåËøôÊòØÊ†áÂáÜËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÔºå‰ΩÜÁé∞Âú®‰∏çÂÜçÊé®Ëçê‰ΩøÁî®„ÄÇ

10. ÂÆ¢Êà∑ÈÄÄË¥ßÊó†ÈúÄÈÄÄÊ¨æ

‰∏öÂä°ÈúÄÊ±Ç

ÂÆ¢Êà∑ÈÄÄÂõûÁ¨¨‰∏âÊñπ‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÊèê‰æõÁöÑÂÖçË¥πÊ†∑ÂìÅÔºåÊó†ÈúÄÂêëÂÆ¢Êà∑ÈÄÄÊ¨æÔºåÁõ¥Êé•ÈÄÄÂõû‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜ„ÄÇ

  • ÂØºËá¥Á≥ªÁªü‰∏≠‰∫ßÁîüÂ§ßÈáè‰∏çÂøÖË¶ÅÁöÑÈÄÄÊ¨æÂá≠ËØÅ

Any help would be highly apprciated!

entry.title: Instalando a API da Calculadora da Reforma Tribut√°ria no BTP
entry.content:
Em julho de 2025 a Receita Federal liberou a primeira vers√£o da ferramenta oficial para c√°lculo da reforma tribut√°ria sobre o consumo. Antes dessa data, o uso era restrito √†s empresas participantes do programa piloto.

O primeiro recurso √© a calculadora online, que recebe os dados da opera√ß√£o e retorna os tributos calculados em tela. Esta calculadora pode ser acessada pelo seguinte link: https://piloto-cbs.tributos.gov.br/servico/calculadora-consumo/calculadora/regime-geral

Por√©m, o recurso mais importante √© a chamada "Calculadora Offline" que permite a instala√ß√£o local e sobretudo a integra√ß√£o com qualquer ERP por meio de uma API.

Esta API foi desenvolvida em Java e Springboot e o download pode ser feito pelo seguinte link: https://consumo.tributos.gov.br/servico/calcular-tributos-consumo/calculadora/calculadora-offline

A calculadora offline possui vers√µes para Windows e Linux via Docker, mas eu quero mostrar aqui como subir esta API no BTP, tornando ela vis√≠vel ao seu ERP ou Middleware (PI, PO, CPI, etc.)

O primeiro passo √© baixar a vers√£o Docker no bot√£o "Baixar Programa". Ser√° baixado um arquivo ZIP de aproximadamente 260MB.

Ao descompactar o arquivo o √∫nico que nos interessa √© o "calculadora.tar.gz"

 

Agora voc√™ vai precisar de uma conta docker (https://www.docker.com) e baixar o Docker Desktop para o sistema operacional de sua prefer√™ncia.

 

A partir deste ponto vamos usar o terminal do seu sistema operacional:

Use o comando "docker login" para iniciar a sess√£o.

docker login

 

Em seguida vamos utilizar o comando "docker save" para criar uma imagem com base no arquivo baixado do site da Receita Federal.

docker save [nome da sua imagem] > calculadora.tar.gz

O pr√≥ximo passo √© carregar a imagem com o c√≥digo-fonte por meio do comando "docker load":

docker load < calculadora.tar.gz

Na sequ√™ncia vamos criar uma tag "1.0" para o nosso novo reposit√≥rio por meio do comando "docker tag":

docker tag [sua imagem]:latest [nome de usu√°rio docker]/[seu reposit√≥rio]:[sua tag]

 

Agora vamos usar o comando "docker push" para fazer o upload do nosso componente para o reposit√≥rio Docker Hub. Aguarde o final do upload.

docker push fapurcino/calculadora-image:1.0

 

Agora vamos fazer o deploy para o BTP via linha de comando. Primeiro voc√™ vai precisar do utilit√°rio CLI, que pode ser baixado gratuitamente em https://docs.cloudfoundry.org/cf-cli/install-go-cli.html

 

Para fazer login no BTP via linha de comando basta digitar "cf login", informar o endpoint e suas credenciais do BTP. Ap√≥s o login, ser√£o listadas todas as subaccounts que voc√™ tem acesso e voc√™ precisar√° escolher qual delas receber√° a API.

cf login

 

 

Para garantir a compatibilidade do Java, crie um arquivo chamado manifest.yml na mesma pasta do arquivo calculadora.tar.gz com o seguinte conte√∫do:

applications:
- name: calculadora-image
  memory: 1G
  docker:
    image: fapurcino/calculadora-image:1.0
  timeout: 180
  env:
    JBP_CONFIG_OPEN_JDK_JRE: '{ jre: { version: 21.+ } }'
  command: /opt/java/openjdk/bin/java -jar calculadora/api-regime-geral.jar --spring.profiles.active=offline --spring.datasource.url=jdbc:sqlite:calculadora/calculadora/db/calculadora-pro.db

 

Com o terminal na mesma pasta digite o comando:

cf push [nome da sua aplica√ß√£o] --docker-image [seu nome de usu√°rio docker]/[seu reposit√≥rio]:[sua tag]

 

 

Ap√≥s a conclus√£o do processo deve aparecer uma linha "running" indicando sucesso. Note que existe uma rota criada em "routes". Esta rota pode ser acessada pelo BTP pelo navegador de sua prefer√™ncia.

 

Veja que ao adicionar o segmento "/api" na URL voc√™ ter√° acesso √† documenta√ß√£o padr√£o swagger e poder√° fazer todas as chamadas desejadas √† API.

https://[rota gerada para sua subaccount]/api

Ou conforme exemplo:

https://calculadora.cfapps.br10.hana.ondemand.com/api

Espero que este post tenha sido √∫til. Curta e compartilhe com outras pessoas que podem achar isso √∫til em seus projetos.

 

Um grande abra√ßo

Fabio Purcino

entry.title: CI/CD & SCTM Setup on SAP BTP (NestJS + React Extensions)
entry.content:
In my previous post, I focused on developer productivity and measurable outcomes. This time, I‚Äôm switching gears to delivery engineering: how we build and ship two independent apps‚Äîa NestJS backend and a React frontend (behind Managed AppRouter)‚Äîas extensions on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, using SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery (CI/CD) and SAP Cloud Transport Management (SCTM).

SAP CI/CD gives us predefined CI/CD pipelines we can configure and run as jobs. 

SCTM adds controlled transport, an import queue, and manual approvals when needed. 

 

What We Deliver (Two Apps, Two Lifecycles)

1) React Frontend (behind Managed AppRouter)

We package the React UI so it‚Äôs served through SAP BTP Managed Application Router, meaning we don‚Äôt maintain our own AppRouter runtime. 

2) NestJS Backend

Standard Node.js service deployed to Cloud Foundry, independently released from the frontend.

 

The CI/CD Flow (End-to-End)

  1. Merge happens into a tracked branch (we use test and master).

  2. Bitbucket webhook triggers a CI/CD job.

  3. CI/CD runs a Cloud Foundry pipeline and builds an MTA from mta.yaml.

  4. In the Release stage, the job uploads the built artifact to a SCTM node.

  5. SCTM puts the transport into the import queue, where we manually forward/import if the node is configured for manual control. 

 

SAP BTP CI/CD service with jobs definition example.

 

SAP BTP Cloud Transport Management service with transport node detail.

 

Our Branch & Job Strategy (Simple and Explicit)

We keep it intentionally ‚Äúboring‚Äù:

  • React repo
    • Job for test
    • Job for master
  • NestJS repo
    • Job for test
    • Job for master

This avoids ‚Äúone job that behaves differently depending on branch logic‚Äù and makes it obvious what ships from where.

 

Our SCTM Strategy (Auditability Over Minimal Clicks)

To improve auditability and clarity for customers, we use separate SCTM nodes per environment and per domain:

  • TEST-FE, TEST-BE

  • PROD-FE, PROD-BE

That‚Äôs four upload nodes for two environments.

Why we do it:

  • Cleaner history (‚Äúfrontend vs backend‚Äù separation without filtering gymnastics)

  • Easier review and approval flows when different people own FE/BE releases

What it costs:

  • More nodes = more configuration + more manual imports

SCTM supports manual control via Import Queue when the node‚Äôs forward mode is Manual. 

SCTM Node configuration detail.

 

SAP CI/CD Setup (What We Configure)

1) Credentials

We create three kinds of credentials:

  • Bitbucket access (clone/pull)

  • Webhook credentials (to trigger builds from merges/pushes)

  • SCTM service key credentials (for ‚ÄúUpload to‚Äù in release)

CI/CD is designed around configuring jobs that run predefined pipelines. 

 

Credentials definition section in SAP BTP CI/CD service.

 

2) Repositories + Webhooks

For each repo in CI/CD:

  • Add repository (Bitbucket Cloud)

  • Attach credentials

  • Configure webhook so merges trigger the job

 

Repositories integration section in SAP BTP CI/CD service.

 

3) Jobs

For each branch job:

  • Select repository + branch

  • Build tool: MTA

  • Build descriptor: mta.yaml (repo root)

  • Optional: lint, unit tests, scans (pre-transport quality gates)

 

Jobs definition section in SAP BTP CI/CD service.

 

In Release:

  • Release type: SCTM

  • Operation: Upload to

  • Node: one of TEST-FE/TEST-BE/PROD-FE/PROD-BE

 

Basic definition of a job including Cloud Transport Management service integration.

 

SCTM Destinations (Deploying to the Right CF Org/Space)

SCTM uses destinations to address deployment targets for MTA deployment on Cloud Foundry. 

If you use OAuth2Password authentication via SAP Cloud Deployment service, SAP notes two critical details:

  • Client ID must be cf

  • Token Service URL must point to Cloud Foundry UAA 

 

Example of a destination configuration needed for SCTM service.

 

What‚Äôs Shared vs. App-Specific

Shared Practices (React + NestJS)

These rules apply to both repos:

  1. mta.yaml lives in the repository root (so CI/CD can reliably find it).

  2. package.json and package-lock.json are in the root.

  3. Dependencies install via npm ci for reproducibility.

  4. Build step is always explicit (no hidden magic).

  5. Only artifacts that passed CI checks get uploaded to SCTM.

 

React App (Managed AppRouter): Minimal MTA Wrapper

Our typical structure:

  • /approuter (Managed AppRouter module/config)

  • /ui (React app)

  • /mta.yaml (root)

  • /package.json (root)

Managed AppRouter is intended to run HTML5 apps without maintaining your own runtime. 

Build logic (conceptually):

  • npm ci

  • npm run build

  • post-step: ensure a manifest.json is present for packaging requirements (even if the React runtime doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúuse‚Äù it)

Important configuration files:

  • mta.yaml
_schema-version: "3.2"
ID: mta_application_fe
version: 0.0.1
modules:
- name: mta_application_fe-approuter
  type: approuter.nodejs
  path: mta_application_fe-approuter
  requires:
  - name: mta_application_fe_html_repo_runtime
  - name: mta_application_fe-destination-service
    group: destinations
    properties:
      forwardAuthToken: false
      name: ui5
      url: https://ui5.sap.com
  parameters:
    disk-quota: 256M
    memory: 256M
- name: mta_application_fe_ui_deployer
  type: com.sap.application.content
  path: .
  requires:
  - name: mta_application_fe_html_repo_host
    parameters:
      content-target: true
  build-parameters:
    build-result: resources
    requires:
    - artifacts:
      - uionboarding.zip
      name: uionboarding
      target-path: resources/
- name: uiapplication
  type: html5
  path: ui_application
  build-parameters:
    build-result: dist
    builder: custom
    commands:
    - npm ci --include=dev
    - npm run build
    - ./ensure-manifest.sh
    - sh -c 'cd dist && jar cfM uiapplication.zip .'
    supported-platforms: []
resources:
- name: mta_application_fe_html_repo_runtime
  type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
  parameters:
    service: html5-apps-repo
    service-plan: app-runtime
- name: mta_application_fe_html_repo_host
  type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
  parameters:
    service: html5-apps-repo
    service-plan: app-host

parameters:
  deploy_mode: html5-repo
  enable-parallel-deployments: true
  • package.json
{
  "name": "application-fe",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "description": "Build and deployment scripts",
  "scripts": {
    "clean": "rimraf resources mta_archives mta-op*",
    "build": "rimraf resources mta_archives && npm run prepare-ui && mbt build --mtar archive",
    "prepare-ui": "mkdir -p resources && cd ui_application && npm install && npm run build && ./ensure-manifest.sh && cd .. && npm run create-ui-zip",
    "create-ui-zip": "cd ui_application/dist && mkdir -p ../../resources && zip -r ../../resources/uiapplication.zip . && cd ../..",
    "deploy": "cf deploy mta_archives/archive.mtar --retries 1",
    "undeploy": "cf undeploy mta_application_fe --delete-services --delete-service-keys --delete-service-brokers"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "mbt": "^1.2.29",
    "rimraf": "^5.0.5"
  }
}
  • ensure-manifest.sh
#!/bin/bash
# Make sure manifest.json exists in the right place
if [ -f "dist/manifest.json" ]; then
  echo "manifest.json already exists in the dist folder"
else
  echo "Copying manifest.json to dist folder"
  cp public/manifest.json dist/
fi
# make sure that xs-app.js exists in the right place
if [ -f "dist/xs-app.json" ]; then
  echo "xs-app.json already exists in the dist folder"
else
  echo "Copying xs-app.json to dist folder"
  cp public/xs-app.json dist/
fi

 

NestJS App: Minimal MTA for a CF Node Service

Structure is standard NestJS:

  • /src

  • /test

  • /package.json (root)

  • /mta.yaml (root)

Build logic (conceptually):

  • npm ci

  • npm run build (which runs nest build)

This ‚Äúthin MTA descriptor‚Äù is enough to let SAP CI/CD build it through the standard MTA path and hand off to SCTM.

Important configuration files:

  • mta.yaml
ID: application-be
_schema-version: '3.3'
version: 1.0.0

modules:
  - name: application-be
    type: nodejs
    path: .
    parameters:
      buildpack: nodejs_buildpack
      memory: 512M
      disk-quota: 1024M
      command: npm run start
    build-parameters:
      builder: custom
      commands:
        - npm ci
        - npm run build
      ignore: ["node_modules/", "test/", "e2e/", "coverage/", ".vscode/"]

    requires:
      - name: malware-scanner
      - name: postgresql-db
      - name: connectivity-service
      - name: destination-service
...
  • package.json
{
    "name": "zapka-parents-be",
    "version": "0.0.1",
    "description": "",
    "author": "",
    "private": true,
    "license": "UNLICENSED",
    "scripts": {
        ...
        "build": "npm install && nest build",
        ...
    },
    "dependencies": {
        ...
    },
}

 

 

General Outcomes: Why This Setup Works for Us

  1. Predictable builds

    Same entry points (mta.yaml, npm ci, explicit build scripts) across both stacks.

  2. Clear audit trail

    CI/CD builds, SCTM transports; SCTM import queue enables controlled promotion. 

  3. Better separation of concerns

    Dev teams focus on code + CI quality gates; deployment approvals happen in SCTM when needed.

 

Conclusion: Control Without Killing Automation

This setup gives us a stable delivery backbone:

  • CI/CD handles automation and repeatability.

  • SCTM provides governance and auditability via nodes and import queues.

Yes, extra nodes create extra manual confirmations‚Äîbut for customer-facing enterprise delivery, the clarity is often worth it.

 

Questions for Discussion (How Do You Do It?)

  1. Do you use one SCTM node per environment, or do you split nodes by domain (frontend/backend) for auditability?

  2. Do you chain nodes strictly (DEV ‚Üí TEST ‚Üí PROD), or allow direct uploads to higher environments?

  3. Where do you enforce manual gates‚Äîonly before PROD, or also between lower environments?

  4. If you split FE/BE: how do you keep transport naming and history readable over time?

  5. What‚Äôs your preferred balance between fewer nodes (less ops effort) vs more nodes (cleaner audit trails)?

entry.title: Re: Extreme performance problems with new application for...
entry.content:
Can you explain this "after some confusing hacks to get it to work"?

What kind of hacks did you do, coding or dependencies or ????

Is this a WEB or Desktop APP?

If I recall the old native Delphi component was a wrapper around the code crpe32.dll engine, that was deprecated back in CR 10.

Lots of old posts on performance using .NET, due to the nature of .NET Framework, lots of resources having to be loaded.

So your noted delays are actually typical.

There are a few ways to work around some of them...

1. Preload a dummy report so it loads all of the dependencies, use dummy reports with the printer define under Page Setup.

1.a. Do not use No Printer, design the report using a real printer:

1.b. Always use Dissociate, this way the Engine will try to find a match if the Design Printer is not found.

1.c. NEVER use Microsoft's EasyPrint, it's inProc print driver, CR has always required a real printer driver when designing reports.

If Server based you MUST install the actual printer being used, same if local PC printing.

If the printer saved in the Report is not found, CR will search for it, which is why you must use Dissociate, so it stops looking for the original.

May explain your noted 1 and 2.

There is a sample VS .NET app for printing, not sure if Delphi can load it, but it explains a lot of How To's when using No Printer, uses a dummy report to load the defaults:

Printing Crystal Reports in .NET

Also note when No Printer is used then USP10 and some of the PC's Default printer properties are used to format the page. Using a real printer then GDIPlus.dll is used to format the page.

Hope that helps....

entry.title: Re: Consuming SAC export API into Excel ODATA feed
entry.content:
@Manvendra_Singh26 

The export url for Dimension Master Data can be augmented with parameters to directly export to a CSV format. The response can be generated in .CSV format using the $format=text/csv parameter in the request. Something like below.

https://<TENANT_URL>/api/v1/dataexport/providers/sac/<PROVIDER_ID>/<DIMENSION_NAME>?$format=csv

This will download the CSV directly and you do not have to use Power Query ODATA connection.

 

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Re: Regarding User Licence..
entry.content:
Here is a link to CR's Licensing Info:

Crystal Reports for Visual Studio Licensing

In short If it's an internal application then one copy of CR Designer is needed, which you likely already own. If it's a sellable product then each install must purchase a copy of Crystal Reports Designer.

YOu can use a Silent Install of CRD, search the Help file on how to create an INI file to manage this step.

You can download the MSI packages to distribute the .NET runtime

Always use the latest SP for Crystal Reports for Visual Studio, must recompile the app after you install the latest SP.

ALSO NOTE: As of this year SAP is no longer building a 32 but runtime package, it's 64 bit but only so you should start looking into upgrading your project to 64 bit.

entry.title: Intelligent Alert Management in SAP Cloud ALM with SAP Build Process Automation
entry.content:
If you ever wonder how to configure custom email notifications for SAP Cloud ALM events or whether notifications were sent to the right team, you‚Äôre in the right place. I‚Äôd also like to cover SAP Build Process Automation‚Äôs fairly new generative AI capabilities and how they can help us configure automations, processes, forms, and rules within BPA.

I‚Äôll guide you through the process using the Certificate Expiry event in SAP Cloud ALM, but the same approach can be applied to other event types as well. In SAP Cloud ALM, certificate expirations are rated as either Warning or Critical, depending on how you‚Äôve configured the thresholds. By default, SAP Cloud ALM may send an email using a template like the following:

SAP Cloud ALM for Operations
Expired Certificate ‚Äì CF Cloud Integration Tech P&P Int
Alert Context: CF Cloud Integration Tech P&P Int
Reported At: 2025-12-03 12:08:57 UTC
Priority: High
Status: In Process

As you can see the default email does not include:
    1, Which certificate (CN/alias/subject) is expired
    2, Expiry date and ‚Äúdays overdue / days remaining‚Äù
    3, Where used (endpoint / integration artifact / runtime)

You may want to enrich the message and send a customized email to the right team.

Let‚Äôs see how we can achieve this...

Context

1, Configure an event in SAP Cloud ALM for the desired monitoring application. In this example, we use Health Monitoring for Integration Suite (Cloud Integration).

2, When we configure an event in SAP Cloud ALM, we can enable alerts and add Operations Automation as an action. If an alert is open, we can start the operation flow manually by clicking Actions. If the event is triggered, the operation automation starts automatically.

3, Once the operation flow is triggered, we can view the execution logs in SAP Build Process Automation under the Monitoring > Processes tab, including the context payload sent from SAP Cloud ALM to BPA.

 

Configuring the workflow:

1, Create a process automation in SAP Build Process Automation

2, If generative AI is enabled in Control Tower, you should see the Generate button.

3, First, create a process using the generative AI functionality. For example:
‚ÄúGenerate a process called ‚ÄòcustomAlert‚Äô with a decision table and an email step.‚Äù
This will create a basic process skeleton:

4, Next, add the process inputs that BPA expects from SAP Cloud ALM (refer: Operation Flow | SAP Help Portal). For an operation automation, you typically receive values such as:

  • automationId
  • timestamp
  • eventDetailsTable (This will be an object, include the certificate details we wish to call‚Ä¶)
  • serviceName       etc..

You must define these as process inputs in BPA‚Äîand you can use generative AI for this as well. For example:

‚ÄòCreate process inputs for rating, timestamp, serviceName, eventName and lmsRole‚Äô

5, Then, add an API trigger.

6, Create a Script Task before the decision table to parse the eventDetailsTable from the payload and either use "rating" from the payload or derive a custom severity (CRITICAL/WARNING) based on the "days until expiry" value. Tiny snippet:

var t = safeParseJson($.context.startEvent.eventDetailsTable);
var rows = (t && Array.isArray(t.rows)) ? t.rows : [];
var overall = "WARNING";

for (var i = 0; i < rows.length; i++) {
var days = parseFloat(rows[i][4]); // Value = days until expiry
if (!isNaN(days) && days <= 7) { overall = "CRITICAL"; break; }
}

$.context.custom.certseverityoverall = overall;

7, Configure a Decision Step for correct email routing:

Click Open Editor. This step determines the notification recipients based on the incoming values and the rules you define..

For example, a CRITICAL severity in PROD should be routed to the on-call team. In contrast, a WARNING severity in DEV can typically be routed to the standard support team.

In the Decision step, define the required inputs and outputs for this routing logic. Add rating and systemType as input parameters, and recipient as the output parameter.

Now, create a rule using generative AI, for example:

‚ÄòIf the rating is CRITICAL, then recipient must be support@oncall.com‚Äô

8, Open the Mail Body Editor as the final step and reference the variables in your custom email.

9, Deploy and Verify:

Deploy the workflow in SAP Build Process Automation, then register it in SAP Cloud ALM via the Operations Automation tab.

Assign it to the ‚ÄúExpired Certificate‚Äù event in Health Monitoring for Integration Suite (Cloud Integration). When the event is triggered, the operation flow will start automatically and send the appropriate email to the appropriate team.

entry.title: Creating and Accessing an IAS Tenant on SAP BTP (Part 2)
entry.content:
In Part 1 of this series, the role of SAP Cloud Identity Services ‚Äì Identity Authentication (IAS) as a foundational component for enterprise-grade SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) implementations was introduced.

This article focuses on creating and accessing an IAS tenant on SAP BTP.
At this stage, no DIV-specific configuration is performed. Instead, the identity foundation required for later integration with DIV is prepared.

 

Positioning in the Overall Architecture

At a high level, IAS acts as a central authentication and authorization layer between corporate identity providers and DIV components.

This architectural positioning corresponds to the enterprise requirements introduced in Part 1, where IAS acts as the central identity layer between corporate identity providers and DIV (Figure 1).

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Figure 1: High-level identity architecture integrating SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) with SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV).

 

Prerequisites

Before starting the setup, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled:

  • An SAP BTP global account
  • A BTP subaccount (existing or newly created)
  • Administrative permissions to:
    • Manage entitlements
    • Create service instances
    • Configure identity services

 

Step 1: Access the SAP BTP Global Account

  1. Open the SAP BTP Cockpit: https://account.hana.ondemand.com/#/home/welcome
  2. Log in using SAP credentials
  3. Select the relevant global account
Note:
In enterprise environments, multiple global accounts may exist (for example, development, test, and production). The correct global account for the DIV implementation must be selected.

 

Step 2: Select or Create a Subaccount

Subaccounts provide logical isolation for different projects, environments, or organizational units.

  1. In the left navigation panel, open Account Explorer
  2. Either:
    • Select an existing subaccount, or
    • Create a new subaccount:
      1. Click Create ‚Üí Subaccount
      2. Enter a display name (e.g. manufacturer-div-test)
      3. Select a region (e.g. AWS, Europe)
      4. Click Create

 

Step 3: Check and Add Cloud Identity Service Entitlements

IAS is provided as part of SAP Cloud Identity Services and must be entitled before it can be consumed within a subaccount.

  1. In the subaccount, navigate to Entitlements 
  2. Search for Cloud Identity Services
  3. If the service is already listed, continue with the next step
  4. If the service is not listed:
    1. Click Edit in the top right corner
    2. Select Add Service Plans (top right)
    3. Search for Cloud Identity Services
    4. Select the service
    5. Choose the default application plan
    6. Click Add Service Plan
    7. Click Save

Good to know:
Each SAP BTP global account includes one free production IAS tenant and one free test IAS tenant.

 

Step 4: Create an IAS Instance

The IAS instance represents the actual IAS tenant that will later serve as the identity provider for DIV.

  1. In the subaccount navigation, go to Services ‚Üí Instances and Subscriptions
  2.  Click Create
  3. Configure the instance with the following values:
    • Service: Cloud identity Service
    • Plan: default
    • Runtime environment: Cloud Foundry
    • Instance name: for example, manufacturer-div-ias-test
  4. Click Create

Provisioning of the IAS tenant typically completes within 1-2 minutes.

 

Step 5: Access the IAS Admin Console

After provisioning is complete, the IAS administration interface becomes available.

  1. In Instances and Subscriptions, locate the newly created IAS instance
  2. Click on the instance name to open the instance details
  3. Open the Admin Console or Dashboard URL (URL format: https://<tenant-id>.accounts.ondemand.com/admin)
  4. Log in using SAP credentials

The IAS Admin Console is the central place for:

  • Managing users and groups
  • Configuring authentication and identity federation
  • Controlling access to DIV wallets and provisioning tenants

 

Result

After completing the steps above:

  • An IAS tenant is successfully provisioned on SAP BTP
  • The IAS Admin Console is accessible
  • No integration with DIV has been configured yet

This completes the identity foundation required for the DIV setup.

 

Read more

‚û°Ô∏è   Continue with Connecting IAS with SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (Part 3)

‚¨ÖÔ∏è   Go back to Why IAS Is Essential for Enterprise DIV Implementations (Part 1)

 

  • Introduction to SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) and Related SSI Blog Posts 
  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Data Spaces 
  • Feature Scope Description for Decentralized Identity Verification (help page)
  • What Are Cloud Identity Services? (help page)
