entry.title: Ariba CIG : Service PO mapping not working
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We are facing one issue when trying to do mapping for a Service PO. Where the Quantity & Price value flip happens for both the Service & Material PO. Below is the requirement

Requirement:

If the PReq Item is a service (i.e. Service Start Date <> blank), then map the:

  • PR Qty field -> PO Price field
  • PR Price field -> PO Qty field

Keep PR UoM field mapped to PO UoM field

Note: We have Item Category = 'M' only as per client requirement.

Based on the above requirement we tried mapping in ‚ÄúPurchaseOrderExportRequest‚Äù. However, we are facing some challenges in our test environment where the desired output is not achievable.

  • Steps Performed: PR Qty field -> PO Price field

1) Mapped Quantity (PurchOrdScheduleDetails_Item) to NET_PRICE(PO_ITEMS)

  •  
  • 2) Added Source condition to the Custom Date (Custom Section)

     

  • 3) Created PR5373. Has 2-line items:

1st Line item has a Commodity code as 'Service' , Service Start & End Date are not blank & Item Category = 'M'. - Here the value flip is successful

Payload: 1st Lineitem

2nd Line item has a Commodity code as 'Equipment' ,Service Start & End Date are Blank , Item Category = 'M'. - Here also the value flip happens which should not happen.

Payload 2nd line item:

 

I believe it is because of looping Custom field takes consideration of the field text(ServiceStartDate) alone in the mapping without considering if it has got a value or not.

So, we would like to understand how we can overcome this situation where we need only Quantity & Price should flip when the ‚ÄúServiceStartDate‚Äù <> Blank. ?

If I add a new Custom Field for Service PO as ‚ÄúService Flag‚Äù in the same Custom section.

Question:  Will the new Custom field will have the same impact just like the above mapping where the mapping will not consider whether the field is Blank / not Blank when present in the Custom section?

entry.title: How We Built a Smart Data Scrambling Solution for SAP SuccessFactors HCM Using SAP BTP
entry.content:
Introduction

In most organizations, HR data is constantly used in non-production systems‚Äîwhether for testing, development, training, or troubleshooting. During my work with SAP SuccessFactors landscapes, I‚Äôve often seen how these environments are created quickly by copying data from Production‚Äîsimply because it‚Äôs convenient and readily available.

The problem is that these environments often contain real employee data. This includes names, dates of birth, national IDs, salary details, phone numbers, and home addresses. From my experience, this is where serious privacy risks begin. Even a small oversight can lead to compliance issues under data protection regulations.

At the same time, simply replacing all values with dummy data does not work. Testing requires realistic data. Reporting hierarchies must remain intact. Validations must still pass. Payroll and downstream integrations must continue to work. I‚Äôve personally faced scenarios where masked data looked safe‚Äîbut broke workflows, reports, or approval processes.

So the real requirement is not just masking‚Äîit is smart anonymization that keeps the data functional while removing all sensitive information. This realization is what led to the idea of building a more intelligent, rule-driven, and enterprise-ready data scrambling solution.

Our Approach

To address this challenge, we built a Data Scrambling Solution for SAP SuccessFactors HCM on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP).

While designing this solution, one of my key goals was to ensure that it feels native to SAP environments‚Äîsecure, scalable, and easy to integrate. Instead of simply overwriting data with meaningless dummy values, the solution intelligently anonymizes employee-related information using randomized and pattern-based substitutes.

What really mattered to me during development was realism. I wanted test and sandbox systems to behave exactly like production‚Äîso validations still pass, workflows still function, and integrations remain intact‚Äîwhile ensuring that no real personal data is exposed.

With this approach, organizations can confidently use non-production systems for testing, training, and demos without compromising data privacy, regulatory compliance, or system integrity.

Key Features and Benefits

1. Comprehensive Data Scrambling

  • The solution scrambles all sensitive HR fields, including employee names, dates of birth, national IDs, phone numbers, email addresses, home addresses, compensation-related information, and more.
  • What makes this approach different is that it preserves referential integrity across key SuccessFactors entities such as Employee Profile, Job Information, Employment Details, and Position data. Relationships between employees, managers, and organizational structures remain intact even after scrambling.
  • As a result, the output remains realistic and fully usable for functional testing, regression testing, and integration testing, ensuring that business processes continue to behave as expected.

2. Configurable Scrambling Rules

  • The solution allows users to define scrambling rules directly from the application at entity level.
  • It supports multiple anonymization techniques, including Randomization, Pattern-based masking, Substitution lists, Pseudonymization
  • These rules are highly flexible and can be tailored to meet specific project requirements, regional regulations, or internal compliance policies.
  • The configuration framework is also designed to support future enhancements, allowing new entities and rule types to be added easily without redesigning the solution.

3. Flexible Execution Options

The solution provides flexible execution modes to suit different project and compliance needs. Users can choose to:

  1. Run full scrambling across the entire dataset
  2. Perform partial scrambling based on Employee groups, Countries, and Selected modules

A simulation mode is also available, allowing users to preview scrambled values before applying them. This helps validate the rules and avoid unintended changes. This selective execution capability ensures that scrambling can be tailored precisely to the required scope without impacting unnecessary data.

4. Realistic and Functional Output

A key design principle of the solution is to ensure that the scrambled data remains fully functional. All transformed values are generated in valid, system-compatible formats, including:

  • Valid date formats
  • Properly structured email addresses and phone numbers
  • Preserved manager‚Äìemployee hierarchy
  • Country-specific and locale-aware formatting

As a result, business processes, workflows, validations, and integrations continue to function normally‚Äîjust without exposing any real personal information.

5. Download Scrambled Data

  • The solution provides a secure option to download scrambled data as exportable files for further analysis and audit purposes.
  • Users can easily export anonymized datasets along with summary logs in standard formats such as CSV and Excel.
  • These downloadable reports make it simple to perform data validation, compliance checks, and quality reviews, ensuring transparency and traceability of the scrambling process.

6. Email Notifications

Once a scrambling job is completed, the system automatically sends an email notification to the user. The notification includes:

  • Access to the scrambled output
  • Processing summary
  • Job completion status

This ensures timely communication and eliminates the need for manual follow-ups or repeated system checks. Users can conveniently access the finalized scrambled dataset directly from their email.

7. Secure SAP SuccessFactors Integration

The solution integrates securely with SAP SuccessFactors using:

  • OAuth-secured OData APIs, 
  • SAP Destination Service, and
  • SAP BTP runtime

All data extraction, scrambling, and updates are performed securely within SAP Business Technology Platform.

Architecture and Technical Stack

The Data Scrambling Solution for SAP SuccessFactors is deployed on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and follows a secure, cloud-native architecture.

Users access the application through SAP Build Work Zone, which acts as the central entry point. The App Router loads the user interface from the HTML5 App Repository and handles authentication using SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS) or a federated identity provider.

Once authenticated, all requests are routed securely to the backend using SAP Destination Service.The backend is built using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). It contains the complete scrambling logic and communicates with SAP SuccessFactors through trusted OData APIs.

To ensure traceability and audit readiness, all activities‚Äîsuch as job execution, errors, and processing details‚Äîare logged using SAP Application Logging Service.

This architecture ensures:

  • Secure data flow
  • Proper authorization
  • Controlled access
  • Full auditability

Solution Flow

  1. User launches the Data Scrambling application from SAP Build Work Zone
  2. Frontend UI (SAPUI5) is loaded via the App Router
  3. User authentication happens through SAP IAS
  4. Requests are forwarded to the CAP backend using SAP Destination Service
  5. Backend fetches data from SAP SuccessFactors via OData APIs
  6. Scrambling rules are applied to sensitive fields
  7. Logs and audit details are recorded
  8. Final scrambled output is generated and shared

Business Value

  • This solution delivers strong business value by addressing both compliance and operational challenges.
  • It protects employee privacy by ensuring that real personal data is never exposed in test, development, or training environments. This significantly reduces the risk of data leaks and regulatory violations.
  • At the same time, it keeps test environments realistic and fully functional. By preserving data formats, relationships, and system behavior, teams can continue to test workflows, reports, and integrations without disruption.
  • The solution also reduces manual effort by automating the entire anonymization process. There is no longer a need for custom scripts, ad-hoc masking, or manual cleanup activities.
  • By eliminating manual handling of sensitive data, it lowers the risk of human errors that often occur during data copying or cleansing.
  • Finally, the solution is designed to be secure and scalable, making it suitable for both small teams and large enterprise landscapes.

Conclusion

Using real HR data in non-production systems introduces serious privacy and compliance risks. At the same time, relying on unrealistic dummy data makes testing ineffective and unreliable.

This Data Scrambling Solution for SAP SuccessFactors HCM bridges that gap by providing a secure, realistic, and automated way to anonymize sensitive employee information. By preserving data structures, formats, and relationships, the solution enables teams to confidently test, train, and troubleshoot without exposing real personal data.

From my own experience working with SuccessFactors integrations and test environments, I‚Äôve seen how much time and risk this approach can save. Instead of manually cleaning data or writing one-off scripts, teams can now rely on a standardized, scalable, and auditable solution.

Ultimately, this is not just about compliance‚Äîit‚Äôs about enabling innovation safely. When teams no longer have to worry about data privacy risks, they can focus on building, improving, and delivering better solutions with confidence.

entry.title: Monitoring Event Mesh from SAP Integration Suite with SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
We are taking one step further with event driven architecture in, now we can monitor event mesh metrics with SAP Cloud ALM.

One thing quickly may come into your mind that we have monitoring option in SAP Integration Suite, then what‚Äôs new with SAP Cloud ALM.

So below are main points where we need SAP Cloud ALM for monitoring Event mesh:

  1. The broker health can be monitored directly through the Broker State card.
  2. Customers can view the historical metrics data based on housekeeping settings in Cloud ALM.
  3. We are sending warning (80%) and critical (95%) alerts for these metrics, which are also configurable by customers.
  4. The biggest advantage of SAP Cloud ALM health monitoring is that customers don‚Äôt need to access the EMIS (Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite) monitoring screen. They can simply add our service to their SAP Cloud ALM dashboard along with other services and monitor everything in one unified view.
  5. Big Picture of multiple event mesh services.

Now we will look in more details to understand above points,

Before monitoring the system let‚Äôs first understand that we need to add system/service (of SAP Integration Suite) into SAP Cloud ALM tenant for monitoring:

If you are customer, then you need to specify your customer id

And with this option, automatically at backed SAP will pull all connected tenants with their included services.

  • Open landscape management app from SAP Cloud ALM tenant. And check your customer ID.


Note: If you encounter problems connecting your managed services or systems to SAP Cloud ALM, please report a case(opens in new tab) using the following components:

  • SV-CLM-INF-CON ‚Äì Connectivity of managed services/systems to SAP Cloud ALM
  • SV-CLM-INF-LMS ‚Äì Landscape Management Service

Please select your SAP Cloud ALM tenant when reporting the case.

 

Activate event mesh monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM

Below are steps to activate monitoring:

  • Open the scope selector of health monitoring app.
  • Select your SAP Integration Suite (Event Mesh) service from the scope selector and apply the selection.

     

  • The SAP Integration Suite (Event Mesh) service will be displayed in the configuration section.
  • Enable the toggle button next to the service name to activate the data collection.

 

 

Monitoring metrics of event mesh

1. Metrics overview:

Component: Broker Statistics

Metrics:

  • Message Consumers - The number of active consumers receiving messages from the broker.

Threshold can be configured as per requirements. Example, here if message consumers value is 80% of 600 then status is warning and if it is 95% of 600 then critical.

  • Active Connections - Shows the number of active system connections to the broker.
  • Broker State - Shows the readiness of the broker.
  • Message Queues - Number of message queues defined in the broker.

2.  Alert

By selecting event mesh service from configuration option, events can be activated.

With this blog, you must have understood how to monitor event mesh service of SAP Integration Suite with SAP Cloud ALM.

 

 


If you want to understand about end-to-end monitoring of integration scenarios of cloud integration, then please follow this  blog 
If you want to check Cloud integration monitoring with SAP Cloud ALM, please follow this Blog

entry.title: More insights, faster resolution: Expanding Base Memory for SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Why this change matters

Customers today are monitoring more systems and services, more integrations, and more user journeys than ever before. With advanced capabilities such as Real User Monitoring, Business Process Monitoring, Business Process Monitoring, Integration Monitoring, and AI-supported analysis, data volumes naturally grow‚Äîand that data is essential to deliver meaningful insights. For example, in Real User Monitoring, change point detection relies on continuously calculated statistical baselines derived from the preceding two weeks.

 

What‚Äôs changing

To better support modern monitoring scenarios and larger landscapes, we are increasing the base and extension memory from 8 GB to 24 GB.

  • Base HANA memory is increased from 8 GB to 24 GB
    ‚Äì Applies to both, base tenants and tenant extensions
  • Base Outbound API monthly data transfer is increased from 8 GB to 24 GB
    ‚Äì Applies to both baseline tenants and tenant extensions
  • Automatic update to 24 GB for all provisioned or procured tenants
  • A memory estimator will be released to support transparent planning of memory requirements
  • The soon to be released Self Monitoring app can be used to check data consumption and trends
  • Changes become effective January 21, 2026

 

What this means for tenant extensions

The SAP Cloud ALM tenant extension offers flexible scaling options. The included memory and outbound traffic entitlements can be used to increase the resources of your existing productive tenant, to provision additional tenants, or to combine both. Memory and outbound traffic are shared across the base tenant and any extension tenants. SAP recommends operating with a single productive SAP Cloud ALM tenant whenever possible.

With the purchase of one tenant extension, you are entitled from day one to a total of 48 GB of SAP HANA memory and 48 GB of outbound traffic per month. These entitlements can be consumed independently and do not require provisioning an additional tenant ‚Äì you may use them entirely to scale your productive tenant.

If an additional tenant is needed, for example for testing or configuration validation, it can be provisioned and the available memory and outbound traffic are dynamically distributed across the productive and test tenants. When purchasing two tenant extensions, up to two additional tenants can be provisioned, with a total of 72 GB of memory and outbound traffic dynamically shared across up to three tenants. At no time is an additional tenant required to benefit from the extra entitlements provided by a tenant extension.

Call to Action

üëâCheck your current data consumption using Health Monitoring
üëâReview your monitoring scope and enable additional use cases where needed
üëâWatch for the upcoming sizing guide to plan future memory requirements confidently

We look forward to your feedback and discussions!

entry.title: Auto Packing with Nested Handling Units in Inbound Delivery ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Automatic Packing with Nested Handling Units in Inbound Delivery ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • Nested Handling Units (HUs) mean packing one Handling Unit inside another Handling Unit.
  • For example, cartons packed into a pallet, where each carton and the pallet have their own HU number.

Step 1: Maintain Packaging Material Types. The menu path is shown in the screenshot below.

Note: I have created 2 Packaging Material types:

  • Pallet
  • Carton

Step 2: Define Material group for Packaging Materials

 

  • Created Packing Material groups for Pallet and Carton.

Step 3: Define Allowed Packaging Materials

  • Map the Packing Material Type with the Packing Material Group

  • Note - For Nested HUs, it is mandatory to cross-map Packing Material Types with Packing Material Groups.

This means:

  • Carton groups must allow pallet types, and
  • Pallet groups must allow carton types,
  • so that inner HUs can be packed into outer HUs without errors.

Step 4: Assign Number Range intervals to Packaging Material Type

  • Assign a number range to the created Packing Material Types for the respective plant and storage location.

Step 5: Created packing materials in MM01 using Material Type VERP and assign the relevant Packing Material Group and Pack. Material Type in the ‚ÄúMatl Grp Pack. Matls, Packing Material type‚Äù fields under the Basic Data view/Sales: General Plant data. Additionally, assign the appropriate HU Type and also created SFG Material.

In this scenario, two packing materials are created:

  • CARTONBOX with Packing Material Type CARTON
  • PALLET1 with Packing Material Type PALLET
  • 42 with SFG type.

 

Step 6:  Create Packing Instructions using T-Code: POP1

  • Please note that the Handling Unit (HU) number is generated only for the Load Carrier maintained in a Packaging Instruction.
  • As a result, to generate HUs for both cartons and pallets, each must be defined as a Load Carrier. Since a Packaging Instruction can contain only one Load Carrier, separate Packaging Instructions are required for cartons and pallets.
  • Based on this approach, the following Packaging Instructions have been created:

  • Created Packing Instruction ‚ÄúAutoPack‚Äù, added Components for Cotton Box.

  • Maintain check profile.

  • Check and save.

  • A separate Packaging Instruction is created for the pallet by adding the PALLET material as Item Category ‚ÄúP‚Äù and the AUTOPACK packaging instruction as Item Category ‚ÄúI‚Äù. Maintain the required quantities, then check and save.

Step 7: For automatic determination of the Packaging Instruction, create a condition record using T-code POF1.

  • Select ‚ÄúRCPT‚Äù standard for Inbound delivery.

  • Assign the SFG material and the ‚ÄòPALLET‚Äô Packaging Instruction in the determination record.

Step 8:  Enable Auto Packing in Delivery Types

  • Selected Standard ‚ÄúEL‚Äù delivery type for Inbound delivery
  • Enabled ‚ÄúAutomatic Packing‚Äù and save

The above are the configuration steps. The functional flow is explained below.

  • Created PO by selecting Confirmation key.

  • Create the inbound delivery, select the line item, and click ‚ÄòAuto Packing‚Äô. The system automatically packs the material.

In this scenario, Material 42 ‚Äì SFG Material is maintained.

  • Each Carton Box is defined to carry 25 KG of SFG material.
  • Multiple Carton Boxes are then packed into a Pallet, where one pallet contains 4 carton boxes.
  • A Purchase Order is created for 100 KG of 42 SFG material.

During Inbound Delivery Auto Packing, the system performs the packing automatically as follows:

  • 100 KG of SFG material is packed into 4 Carton HUs (25 KG each).
  • These 4 Carton HUs are nested and packed into 1 Pallet HU.

This demonstrates Nested Handling Unit (HU) auto packing, where inner Carton HUs are packed into an outer Pallet HU, and each level is assigned its own HU number automatically by the system.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Category Management 2602 Release Highlights
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Source to Contract Community, and welcome to this latest blog post on the exciting updates coming to SAP Ariba Category Management. This first quarter of 2026, SAP Ariba Category Management updates focus on turning strategy into action, strengthening risk and cost visibility, and making category managers‚Äô day-to-day work simpler and more accountable. The changes are straightforward to adopt and deliver clear business value: faster decision cycles, better traceability, tighter governance, and better control of customizations.

1. Enhancements to External Factors Analysis Tool (ARBCATA-574)

The External Factors Analysis Tool now lets you create risk assessments directly from the External Factors Analysis page, attach supporting links or files, and link or create factors while working in the Risk Assessments page. Exported PDFs include assessment and attachment details, and terminology has been simplified to ‚ÄúKey Factors‚Äù across the Manage Configurations app and the Develop Strategy and Plan app.
The result - richer, context-aware records that reduce manual follow-up and make stakeholder reporting and audits far easier.

The above image shows a new button Create now available in the Risk Assessment section. This allows you to create a risk for the external factor as needed

The above image shows a new section Attachments now available in the page used to add attachments in the form of links or files as additional resources.

The above images shows a new button Create now available in the External Factors Analysis section allowing you to create an external factor for the risk as needed.

 

2. Ability to manage tasks on initiatives (CATMAN-466)
The Initiatives tool include a Tasks section where you can create, edit, delete, and update task status. Task owners can be given a ‚ÄúCan complete own tasks‚Äù permission and receive assignment notifications. Turning initiatives into assignable work increases accountability, improves progress visibility, and shortens the path from plan to delivery.

The above image shows a new section Tasks available in the Initiatives page, used to create, edit, and delete tasks associated with initiatives.

You can also update the task status by selecting Set as Started or Set as Completed buttons shown in above image

A new permission, Can complete own tasks, is now available in the Add Collaborators dialog, as shown in above image


3. Enhanced Cost Structure Analysis with Cost Models and Two-Level Cost Structure (ARBCATA-490)

With this feature, it is possible to define and assign cost models centrally and associate them with cost-structure documents. Cost charts now show two levels of cost components, exposing both top-level and secondary drivers so sourcing teams can compare scenarios and negotiate from a clearer view of supplier economics.

In above image you can see a new option, Cost Models, now available in the Strategy and Plan dropdown menu. Select Cost Models to create, edit, or delete cost models.

The Cost Models page is shown above. Use Create to add a new cost model, or select an existing one to edit, activate, inactivate, or delete it.

 

A new field, Cost Model, is now available on the Cost Structure page, shown above. You can use this field to associate cost structure documents with a cost model.

 

The Cost Structure page now displays a graph showing the two-level cost structure components, as seen above


4. Enhancements to Risk Assessments in SAP Ariba Category Management and Trend Monitoring (ARBCATA-513)
This feature introduces the following user interface enhancements for risk assessments in SAP Ariba Category Management. Changes include a standardized two-level risk structure that can be configured in the Manage Configurations , improved filtering, and a consolidated risk trend chart. These changes make risk comparisons consistent across assessments and give managers a fast, visual sense of how risks evolve over time.

A new Risk Categories section is now available (seen in above image) for every risk type on the Strategy and Plan  Risk Types page, allowing you to select a risk type and associate relevant risk categories with it.

The above image shows new filtering options available on the Risk Assessments page

A new risk score tag is displayed at the top of the screen for risk score analysis, as seen in above image

5. Enhancements to Manage Category Profile and Monitor Strategy Execution Pages (ARBCATA-568) 

Category profiles and Strategy and Plan Documents now appear in tables with extra filters, letting you find the right documents without extra clicks. The streamlined layout speeds discovery for managers and administrators and reduces navigation overhead.

The Manage Category Profile page now offers a comprehensive table listing category profiles with search filters, as seen above

 

In above image you can see the Monitor Strategy Execution page now offers a comprehensive table listing strategy and plan documents with search filters, allowing access to all documents irrespective of their status.

6. Ability to Use Custom Entities in Custom Tools of the Strategy and Plan Document (ARBCATA-539)
A new Extensibility Portal app is now available in the SAP Ariba Category Management launchpad which can be used to create custom entities and define custom fields for the entities. You cab then include the custom entities in custom tools, and personalize layouts with adapt UI functionality. These enhancements help capture organization-specific data for specific business purposes and reporting needs without heavy development work.

The new Custom Component option, seen in above image

 

Go ahead and review these items with your category leads and administrators to identify immediate wins - define or update cost models, clean up custom tools, and update playbooks to reflect task-based initiative management and richer risk reporting.

And, stay tuned for more enhancements and continue to leverage SAP Ariba Category Management to drive business success!

entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration ‚Äì Getting started with Google Pub/Sub Adapter
entry.content:
Google Pub/Sub is a reliable messaging tool that lets your systems talk to each other securely using 'topics.' It‚Äôs great for sharing data in real-time across different cloud platforms. With the Google Pub/Sub adapter in SAP CPI, you can easily send or receive messages, making it much simpler to connect your SAP processes with Google Cloud 

The Google Pub/Sub Adapter is available in both sender and receiver modes to streamline message-based workflows and comes in two variants ‚Äî REST and gRPC. 

Key Features 

  • Publish single messages (Basic) or multiple messages (Advanced) at once. 
  • Use gRPC for real-time performance or REST for polling at defined intervals. 
  • Google Pub/Sub accepts only Base64-encoded data, and the adapter can handle encoding automatically. 
  • Provides multiple post-processing options: Acknowledge after Successful Processing, Acknowledge Immediately, and Do not Acknowledge.  
  • Supports‚ÄØAuthentication via OAuth2 service account authentication and Workload Identity Federation.  

Practical Use Case Walkthrough 
 
In this section, we will demonstrate how to send SalesOrder data to a topic using the Google Pub/Sub Receiver adapter and then read the message again with the Google Pub/Sub Sender adapter, using the REST protocol for messaging. 

Publish a Message using Google PubSub Receiver Adapter 

Prepare Payload in Content Modifier‚ÄØ 
 
For the demonstration, we hardcode the SalesOrder data into the message body. In real time, you can dynamically store the payload from the source system. 

Configure the Google Pub/Sub Receiver Adapter 

Connection‚ÄØtab: 

Parameter‚ÄØ 

Description‚ÄØ 

Address‚ÄØ 

Specify the hostname to connect Google Pub/Sub. 

Authentication Type‚ÄØ 

Select the method for authentication to Google Pub/Sub. 

  • OAuth2 Service Account 
  • Workload Identity Federation  

OAuth2 Token URL‚ÄØ 

Specify the OAuth2 Token URL which identifies as the authorization server for producing a JWT token internally.  

Client Email‚ÄØ 

Specify Google Service Account Client Email. 

Private Key Alias‚ÄØ 

Specify the Google Service Account Private Key for authentication.‚ÄØ 

Scope‚ÄØ 

Specify the scope of the connection to Google Pub/Sub service. 

Reuse‚ÄØConnection‚ÄØ 

Enable the reuse of connection objects from the internal connection pool which in turn improves the network turnaround time for multiple communications to the same end point. 

Connection Timeout (in ms)‚ÄØ 

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for the connection to be established with Google Pub/Sub service.‚ÄØ 

Response Timeout (in ms)‚ÄØ 

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for a response message to be received with Google Pub/Sub service.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

Publish Message using Google Pub/Sub Adapter 

Now let‚Äôs navigate to the‚ÄØProcessing‚ÄØtab, select the‚ÄØEntity as‚ÄØTopic, and select the operation as Publish Message for the use case. 

Also, provide the project ID and topic ID created on the Google Pub/Sub server. 

Processing Tab: 

Parameter 

Description 

Entity  

Select the entity for message processing:‚ÄØ 

  • Topics‚ÄØ
  • Subscriptions‚ÄØ 

Operation‚ÄØ 

Select the operation to be performed.‚ÄØ 

  • Publish Message
  • List‚ÄØ 

Project ID  

Specify the Google Pub/Sub project ID.  

Topic ID  

Specify the Topic ID created on Google Pub/Sub service 

Operation Type  

Select the type of operation  

  • Basic 
  • Advanced  

Encode Data  

Select the checkbox to encode data to Base64 

Ordering key  

Specify the ordering key for this message.   

Message Attributes‚ÄØ 

Specify multiple message attributes as key value pairs. 

Once you run the iflow, you can see the message processed successfully. 

In addition, you can see that the Sales Order message was successfully published to the Google Pub/Sub service. 

Read a Message using Google Pub/Sub Sender Adapter 

The Google Pub/Sub Sender Adapter is available in gRPC and REST formats. For this demonstration, we're using the REST variant. 

Processing Tab: 

In the Google Pub/Sub Sender Adapter, provide the Subscription ID and Project ID from which the message will be read on the Google Pub/Sub Server.  

You can also select the post-processing action once the message has been polled from the Google Pub/Sub Server. 

Once the iflow is successfully deployed, we can check it in the monitoring page. In response, we can see the message body. 

Conclusion: 

The Google Pub/Sub adapter in SAP CPI brings integrations to life by allowing real-time, event-driven communication between SAP and Google Cloud. It enables CPI to easily publish and receive messages at scale, making integrations faster, more responsive, and loosely linked. The adapter's cloud-native design enables the creation of modern, durable integrations that can quickly change with business needs. 

Quick Links: 

  • For information about Google Pub/Sub Sender adapter configuration, see  SAP Help | Google Pub/Sub Sender Adapter.‚ÄØ 
  • For information about Google Pub/Sub Receiver adapter configuration, see  SAP Help | Google Pub/Sub Receiver Adapter.‚ÄØ 
  • For detailed information about the Google Pub/Sub adapter, see Google Pub/Sub Adapter Guide 

The next blog will take this further with an exciting new use case ‚Äî so stay tuned for more insights and updates!

entry.title: UoM changed in Va02 not reflecting in MB51
entry.content:
Hi,

A sales order is created in VA01 with order quantity in bottles. After saving the order, the entry is showing in MB51.  Then the user goes to VA02 to change the unit from bottles to Cases. After saving the order when checking MB51, the new units (CS) and the converted quantity not showing in the list of MB51. 

When debugged, I could see that MSEG table is not hit for any updates during the process and I can see that MB51 fields are coming from MSEG.

I would like to understand if this is expected behavior or if there is anything I am missing. If I cannot see the changes in MB51, where should I check?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Mass upload for Custom Business Object in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction:

We can create a Custom business object using Key user extensibility in SAP Public cloud. We can also create a USER INTERFACE to maintain a database record.

Though we often have a requirement to do one time mass data upload in such CBO. One would have a hard time to do so with standard available options. I have tried out to cover this scenario in this blog post.

Problem Statement:

Custom Business Objects created via Key User Extensibility in SAP Public Cloud by default allows single record maintenance through the user interface, but do not support mass data uploads natively.

Solution:

This workaround involves enabling service generation for the CBO to expose it as an OData service, creating a custom communication scenario and arrangement, and using the service URL with Postman to post data entries individually or in bulk.

Here are the following steps:

  • Create a Custom Business object (CBO) Creating Custom Business Objects | SAP Help Portal
  • Make sure to check Service Generation, so the CBO can be called via OData and User Interface if you want to create database entry using a Screen manually.

     

  • Add required fields and business logic in the CBO
  • Publish it
  • Assign CBO to Custom Communication Scenario
  • Create Custom Communication Arrangement for Custom Communication Scenario created above
  • You will then find your Service URL for your CBO ‚Äì Under Inbound Service section. Your CBO is now exposed as OData service.
  • We are now ready to use this Service URL in Postman

  • You can now put below Headers for your POST call



  • Test with a single entry. Put your data in JSON format under Request BODY (Choose option RAW)



  • Hit Send button and table record is created. That means you are all set to perform mass update.

  • Mass upload process:
    Prepare data in Excel, convert it to JSON array format, and use Postman‚Äôs Runner feature with the JSON file to iterate POST requests for each record. This approach circumvents the limitation of posting multiple records in a single request and allows successful mass loading of data into the CBO using a *.JSON file.

    Here are the following steps:

  • First create an excel with required data.
  • Now convert this file in JSON format file. One can also use available online tools for this purpose (as per your IT compliance).
  • Here is a sample for above excel data into JSON format. File name is data.JSON

     

  • Observe that it is in an array format, so everything will be within [ .. ]

Also, all rows should be entered using the same structure within {..} separated by Comma.

  • Now here is a catch, if you place multiple records in request body, then system will not allow you to do the same and throws an error.
  • To overcome this, we must consider below steps.

  • Put your variables to pick these values from JSON file. For that, you need to update your request body. An example below for our scenario.

 

  • Find out the Runner option in Postman. Most likely it‚Äôs on the top or bottom of your App.

     

 

  • Now choose your data.JSON file from your local machine.

     



  • A preview popup will be displayed with potential values. Choose option USE LOCALLY.

 

 

  • Now drag and Drop your Collection request, so that it will be placed one by one using your data. JSON file.

 

 

  • Ensure that only required request is selected from your collection. In our scenario, I am choosing POST request.

     

  • Now you‚Äôre ready to execute your Mass load request. Click on RUN MY COLLECTION button.

     

Request is processed successfully. Here is a snapshot of response body.

  • Finally, we can see the records in our CBO.

 

Final Remarks:

Mass data upload into Custom Business Objects in SAP Public Cloud is not supported out-of-the-box, but with the right combination of service generation, OData exposure, and Postman‚Äôs Runner feature, this limitation can be overcome. By converting your Excel data into JSON format and leveraging Postman collections, you can automate record creation and achieve a smooth bulk upload process.


This approach provides a practical workaround for one-time or recurring mass data loads, saving significant manual effort and ensuring consistency in your CBO entries. While it may not be as seamless as native integration tools, it empowers key users and developers to handle real-world scenarios efficiently without waiting for additional product features.


In short, with a bit of setup and the right tools, you can transform what seems like a limitation into a manageable process-making Custom Business Objects far more versatile in SAP Public Cloud.

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: What Risks to Look Out for in 2026
entry.content:
In previous years, I used to release a blog ranking the top risks for the year to come ‚Äì as per analysts, experts and business leaders insights, but this has proven quite impossible this year.

There are mainly 2 reasons for this:

  1. The great discrepancies in views in what the main business threats are ‚Äì depending on the industry and region. When there was previously somewhat of a consensus on top risks, for 2026 onwards, the risk landscape seems be quite ‚Äúfractured‚Äù with diverging opinions
  2. The risks are more and more interconnected. An impact on one category directly increases the likelihood of adverse events in another category from occurring

As a result, instead of playing Nostradamus, I decided to try and summarize this complexity without objectively granting more weight to one area over another.

 

10 business threats to look out for ‚Äì in no particular order

 

Geopolitics

 

With the rise of nationalism and protectionism, the multilateral globalization that fostered international commerce for decades has ceased to exist. Not that global trade won‚Äôt continue of course, but the rules are being rewritten due to weakened governing institutions. Whereas trade agreements were previously the result of year long negotiations, this is no longer the case. And it questions their longevity. Will these quickly negotiated treaties continue to apply should administrations change or the legislator rule against their implementation?

This risk category and associated events directly impact Supply Chain and Economic Conditions, but also Security since (re-)militarization and conflicts are direct consequences of shifts in the geopolitical technical plaques.

 

Human Resources and Talent Management

 

Despite globalization of the labour market, talent shortage in in-demand sectors and functions is obvious. This is further heightened by inadequate skills in these areas.

Combined with economic uncertainty and reduction in workforce for some industries, a direct consequence is a much more competitive market for both employees ‚Äì who must fight for limited number of roles, and for employers ‚Äì where some roles are not filled due to lack of qualified applicants.

A perfect example here is Security ‚Äì and especially cybersecurity, where it is estimated that 87% of organizations are experiencing a shortfall of security talent with 3,5 million unfilled jobs worldwide.

Going back to Geopolitics, new restrictions in visa allocations decided by governments further increases the velocity of this risk as it impedes the movement of workers to countries with higher demand.

 

Artificial Intelligence

 

One of the most recent and yet pervasive top risk category is Artificial Intelligence. The more AI develops, the more it offers business opportunities but also the more it opens the door to new risk types. Ranging from legal threats with IP infringement for instance where an AI model can make use of data without licensing or authorization, to economic with Digital Disruption completely reinventing a market and even rendering obsolete Business Models, it has since quickly increased for Security risk levels as well with autonomous AI-driven cyber-attacks in the digital world or even self-directed drones in the physical world. In this regard, the Science and Security Board of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists who contribute to setting the time on the Doomsday Clock summarize it better than I would: ‚ÄúThe potential for this particular technology [AI] to constitute an existential threat on its own is highly speculative, but as succeeding generations of such models are released, the potential dangers, existential or otherwise, will increase.‚Äù

A key challenge to come will be providing trust and confidence in AI systems. This could come with the implementation of Compliance and Regulations frameworks such as AI governance structures that maintain human oversight while supporting the achievement of AI‚Äôs automation promises. Recent AI legislative acts around the global are already targeting this, and their effectiveness will be crucial in achieving this balance.

 

Digital Disruption

 

Fostered by AI but not only, Digital Disruption has clearly started with the emergence of new technologies and continues to be a top risk. In addition to bringing new technological landscapes that have their own challenges, organizations also face digital disruption due to changing consumer behaviour in the era of e-commerce and digital-first customer journeys.

This is not only redesigning organizations‚Äô marketing approaches, but it‚Äôs also impacting sales, delivery, customer support‚Ä¶ and much more! And in some extreme cases, completely redefining Business Models.

 

Security ‚Äì Cyber and Physical

 

As already highlighted in the Geopolitics and Artificial Intelligence categories, there is no doubt that Security is a major concern for organizations. Physical security with conflict zones extending in geographical scope but also now entering the cyberspace and creating a new age of hybrid attacks where crippled infrastructure poses a vital threat.

It is therefore not surprising that the Global Peace Index has worsened and that the Doomsday Clock is inching towards midnight, with only 89 seconds to spare.

But increased security threats are also the result of in-house deficiencies. For instance, Cybersecurity experts highlight that the increase in unmonitored vulnerabilities leaving companies exposed can be attributed to unsanctioned AI usage.

 

Economic Conditions

 

Previous year‚Äôs trend on rising costs ‚Äì especially energy and natural resources, seem to have stabilized but are still very fragile and a persistent concern for organizations. If the global consumer price index (CPI) shows a slight inflationary decrease in 2024 versus 2023, it remains above pre‚Äëpandemic norms.

On the downside, continued tariff driven trade tensions will likely add pressure in 2026 and render pricing and sourcing strategies much more volatile due to an unpredictable economic environment and Geopolitical decisions.

 

Business Model

 

‚ÄúBusiness resilience‚Äù and ‚ÄúShift in consumer behaviour‚Äù are the most cited keywords in reports and interviews when it comes to root causes of evolving business models.

Consumer behaviour is not just about the way customers purchase a product or a service, it is also their spending pattern of course. With pointers indicating significant slowdown in recent months, mostly due to Economic Conditions and proactive cost reduction.  

For organizations that have focused on leveraging technology to fuel a new business model or overall preparedness, analyst feedback points out that the return on investment from Artificial Intelligence and Digital initiatives has been limited, often hindered by siloed data, misalignment with business needs or misguided decisions based on flawed AI outputs.

 

Compliance and Regulations

 

I have already addressed the impetus of Artificial Intelligence governance earlier and will address Sustainability reporting just below and it is undeniable that these 2 drivers will continue to spearhead new compliance requirements across the globe.

In addition, the mandate for companies to demonstrate continuous oversight of their IT systems and their incident response will remain very high, as requested by requirements such as the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) and others.

As a matter of fact, associated data sovereignty directives will be increasingly strict and complex, driven by these new regulatory frameworks and heightened concerns about cross-border data flows, and cyber resilience. As a matter of fact, in this area alone, global regulations are escalating in response to growing Geopolitical tensions with over 135 countries having already implemented some form of data protection and sovereignty legislation.

 

Sustainability

 

If Sustainability initiatives have slowed down with many companies having reassessed or delayed investments and program deliveries, it can be traced back to more limited regulatory enforcement of legislation than planned, reduced global cooperation on climate change‚Ä¶ and of course overall market uncertainty due to Economic Conditions.

That being said, there is an overwhelming consensus across all reports and interviews that sustainability and climate concerns continues to be a top risk. For companies and for the world. If escalating extreme weather conditions is driving higher insurance costs and operational disruptions, policy uncertainty around the low‚Äëcarbon transition and additional sustainability reporting rules in leading economic blocks are a reality.

It is no longer the case that companies use the green agenda as a reputation boost, but they truly must deliver on measurable sustainability performance gains and demonstrate exemplarity.

 

Supply Chain

 

Last but certainly not least in this list of top risks is Supply Chain. To me, it represents the most interconnected category. Any adverse event in another section will increase the likelihood of its own risks manifesting.

For instance:

  • Geopolitics: an increase in trade wars can lead to new sanctions, exports and/or imports hence, de facto, impacting supply and delivery capabilities.
  • Security: attacks ‚Äì whether physical or cyber on suppliers, on operational sites, or IT systems can result in system shutdowns, once again preventing the company from procuring the necessary materials for producing and distributing its good and services.
  • Economic Conditions: with fluctuating prices and rapidly evolving consumer demands, forecasting and demand planning is becoming increasingly complex.
  • Compliance and Regulation: requirements such as the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive, the Digital Operational Resilience Act or even the EU AI Act extend transparency and accountability to the company‚Äôs third-party providers.
  • Sustainability: extreme weather events such a floods, droughts or hurricanes are causing more frequent and severe operational disruptions, damaging infrastructure, leading to port closures, and blocking key trade routes.

 

What else?

 

This is the question that most business leaders I interviewed answered once they had provided their views: what else did I miss?

Despite being somewhat on the horizon for the following year, at the end of 2024, tariffs were not ranked as the major concern for many organizations. That was until the US administration enforced new rules, and this completely flipped the risk landscape upside down in just a few days. From then on, at least 50% of my ‚Äúrisk conversations‚Äù revolved around this topic. At least for the first half of 2025.

So, I turn the question to you: is there another similar emerging risk that I haven‚Äôt captured in this summary that you think should feature? If so, feel free to add your suggestions in the comments section of this blog!

If you are interested in comparing this picture to previous years‚Äô reports, then I have listed them below for your convenience:

  • GRC Tuesdays: What Risks to Look Out for in 2025
  • GRC Tuesdays: What Risks to Look Out for in 2024
  • GRC Tuesdays: What Risks to Look Out for in 2023

And if you are interested in learning more about SAP solutions for Governance, Risk, and Compliance, feel free to fill-in the demo request form!

entry.title: Step-By-Step Guide: Creating Your First RAP Application using OData V4 and Transporting to Quality
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog, we will walk through the detailed steps to create your first RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming Model) application and correctly move it to the Quality system. This blog also highlights mandatory steps before transport and common mistakes that beginners usually make, based on real project experience.

Target Audience & Prerequisites

  • ABAP developers who are new to RAP
  • Basic knowledge of CDS Views and ABAP Development Tools (ADT)
  • System used: SAP S/4HANA (On-Premise / Private Cloud)
  • Exposure type: OData V4
  • Scenario covered: Basic Read-only RAP application

    Mandatory Objects in a RAP Application:

    • Package
    • Interface CDS View
    • Projection CDS View (Optional we can directly create service definition on Interface view also)
    • Service Definition
    • Service Binding
  1. Create Package: 

    Create a package in ADT:

    • Right-click on project ‚Üí New ‚Üí ABAP Package
    • Enter package name and description
    • Do not create it as a local package ($TMP)
    • Capture it in a transport request     
    • Only transportable packages can be moved to Quality and Production systems.

    •  

  2. Interface CDS View: A CDS View is a virtual data model in ABAP that defines how data from database tables is accessed and represented. In RAP, it often serves as the ‚ÄúInterface View.‚Äù

    1. Why It Matters:

      • Reusable logic: Centralizes data access for transactional and analytical purposes.
      • Foundation: Serves as the starting point for business object modeling in RAP.

    2. Steps:

      • Right-click your database table (e.g., ZTRAVEL_RAJ_M), select New Data Definition.
      • Provide a name, description, and use the Define View Entity template.
      • Assign to transport, activate, and check for errors.

      •  

  3. Service Definition: The Service Definition specifies which data elements (entities) of a RAP business object are exposed as OData services.

    1. Why It Matters:

      • Exposure Layer: Decides what consumers (e.g., Fiori apps, external APIs) can interact with.
      • It‚Äôs the contract between your backend logic and external consumers.
                                                                                                         

    2. Steps:

      • Right-click on the projection view, select New Service Definition.
      • Name, description, assign transport, and activate.
      • This exposes your RAP objects as a service.

      •  

  4. Service Binding: Service Binding links a service definition to an actual communication protocol (such as OData V4) and activation state.
    1. Why It Matters:
      • Enables Consumption: Without binding, your service cannot be called or used.
      • Protocol Choice: Determines how front ends communicate with your service (e.g., OData V4 for Fiori/UI5 apps).

    2. Steps:

      • Right-click on the service definition, select New Service Binding.
      • Choose OData V4 protocol (for most Fiori/RAP apps).
      • Assign transport, describe, finish, and activate.

      •  

      •  

  5. Why You Should NOT Publish from ADT: Publishing directly from ADT is meant only for local testing.

    1. Issues with ADT Publishing

      • Service is registered as a local ($TMP) object
      • Cannot be transported to Quality or Production
      • Not supported for productive landscapes

    2. Correct Way: Publish via /IWFND/V4_ADMIN

      • Transaction /IWFND/V4_ADMIN is the recommended way to publish RAP services.

    3. Steps: 
      • Open /IWFND/V4_ADMIN and click Publish Service Groups

      •  

      • Enter System Alias = LOCAL, Service Binding name click on get service groups

      •  

      • Select service and Publish

      •  

      • From the service group list, right click on your service group and click on transport publishing. It will prompt for customizing TR enter the transport and save. After that Click on transport routing assignment and capture in the customizing TR.

      •  

      •  

      • Service is now published

      •  

  6. Preview: Finally, let‚Äôs preview the application to verify that the service is working as expected. 

    •  

Conclusion: 

  • In this blog, we learned how to create a basic RAP application and the correct approach to publish and transport OData V4 services to the Quality system.
  • Using /IWFND/V4_ADMIN ensures transport safety and helps avoid common deployment issues that beginners often face.

Note: 

To customize the user interface of your RAP application, add appropriate UI annotations in the CDS view (interface or projection, depending on your design). Common annotations include @ui.headerInfo, @ui.lineItem, and @ui.selectionField.

After publishing the service, share the service URL (available in the Service Binding) with the Fiori development team so they can create the required Fiori tile.
After transporting to the Quality system, SICF activation is a manual step. Without activating the relevant SICF nodes, the service will not be accessible. Coordinate with your Basis team to complete this step.

entry.title: Transport SAC Objects(Folders, Model, Dimensions, Data Action) and Create Folder Using REST APIs
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I am able to copy a story from one folder to another in SAP Analytics Cloud using REST APIs.

Now I want to do the same programmatically for other objects:

  • Folder
  • Model
  • Dimensions
  • Connections
  • Data Actions

Additionally, I want to create a folder under Public > MyFiles using REST APIs (or any other supported programmatic way).

My questions:

  1. Which REST APIs are supported to transport these objects to another folder?
  2. If REST APIs are not supported for some objects, what is the recommended alternate approach?
  3. Is there any API available to create folders programmatically in SAC?

Thanks

‰æõÂ∫îÈìæ‰∏éË¥®ÈáèÁÆ°ÁêÜËÉΩÂäõÊèêÂçá

Âú®SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602‰∏≠Ôºå‰æõÂ∫îÈìæ‰∏éË¥®ÈáèÁÆ°ÁêÜÁöÑËÉΩÂäõÂæóÂà∞‰∫ÜÊòæËëóÊèêÂçá„ÄÇ‰æõÂ∫îÈìæÁÆ°ÁêÜÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÂ¢ûÂº∫Ë¶ÜÁõñ‰∫ÜÁâ©ÊµÅË∑®‰∏ªÈ¢ò„ÄÅËÆ¢ÂçïÊâøËØ∫„ÄÅÂ∫ìÂ≠òÁÆ°ÁêÜ„ÄÅÂ∫ìÂ≠òÂàÜÊûê‰∏éÊéßÂà∂„ÄÅ‰ª•Âèä‰ªìÂ∫ìÁÆ°ÁêÜÁ≠â„ÄÇË¥®ÈáèÁÆ°ÁêÜÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÂàôÂú®Ë¥®ÈáèËÆ°Âàí„ÄÅË¥®ÈáèÊ£ÄÈ™åÂíåË¥®ÈáèÊîπËøõÁ≠âÈ¢ÜÂüüËøõË°å‰∫ÜÁ≥ªÁªüÊÄßÁöÑ‰ºòÂåñ‰∏éÊèêÂçá„ÄÇÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÈù¢Á§∫‰æãÔºö

Â∫ìÂ≠òÁÆ°ÁêÜ ‚Äì È¢ÑÁïô

Âú®ÊúÄÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨Êõ¥Êñ∞‰∏≠ÔºåÈ¢ÑÁïôÊìç‰ΩúÊµÅÁ®ãÂæóÂà∞‰∫ÜÊòæËëóÂ¢ûÂº∫„ÄÇÁî®Êà∑Áé∞Âú®ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøá ‚ÄúÁÆ°ÁêÜÈ¢ÑÁïôÈ°πÁõÆ‚Äù Â∫îÁî®ÔºåÁõ¥Êé•Âü∫‰∫éÈ¢ÑÁïôÂàõÂª∫Â∫ìÂ≠òËΩ¨ÂÇ®ËøáË¥¶ÔºàÁßªÂä®Á±ªÂûã 311ÔºâÔºåÊó†ÈúÄÊâãÂä®ÂàáÊç¢ÂíåÈáçÂ§çÂΩïÂÖ•„ÄÇÊâßË°åËΩ¨ÂÇ®ÂêéÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüËá™Âä®Ë∑≥ËΩ¨Ëá≥ ‚ÄúÁÆ°ÁêÜÈ¢ÑÁïôÁâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅ‚Äù Â∫îÁî®ËøõË°åËøáË¥¶ÔºåËøáË¥¶ÊàêÂäüÂêéËá™Âä®ÁîüÊàê‰∏§Êù°Áâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅÔºö‰∏ÄÊù°ÂèëË¥ßÔºå‰∏ÄÊù°Êî∂Ë¥ß„ÄÇ

 Ëøô‰∏ÄÂ¢ûÂº∫‰ºòÂåñ‰∫ÜÂ∫ìÂ≠òËΩ¨ÂÇ®‰∏éÈ¢ÑÁïôÁÆ°ÁêÜÁöÑÊï¥ÂêàÔºåÂáèÂ∞ëÊìç‰ΩúÊ≠•È™§ÔºåÊèêÂçáÂ∑•‰ΩúÊïàÁéáÔºåÂπ∂Â¢ûÂº∫‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ãÁöÑÂèØËøΩÊ∫ØÊÄß„ÄÇÁî®Êà∑ÂèØ‰ª•Âø´ÈÄüÊü•ÁúãÁâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅËØ¶ÊÉÖÔºåËΩªÊùæËé∑ÂèñËØ¶ÁªÜ‰ø°ÊÅØÔºåÊòæËëóÊèêÂçáÁâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅÁÆ°ÁêÜÁöÑÊïàÁéáÂíåÊï∞ÊçÆÂèØËØªÊÄß„ÄÇ

entry.title: Re: SAP PM Task List Selection Based on Maintenance Activ...
entry.content:
Greetings,

I think per standard this can be acheived only manually. If you would like to automate it then some development might be required.

You need to establish a link between maintenance activity type and task list. Classification class type 018 can be used for that. Below is an example based on your requirement. Classification class 018 is used to clasify task list header.

In the caharacteristics values I would use the same values as you have in customizing for maintenance activity types:

SPRO -> Plant Maintenance and Customer Service -> Maintenance and Service Processing -> Maintenance and Service Orders -> Functions and Settings for Order Types -> Maintenance Activity Type

Some possible solutions for development team:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/assign-task-list-on-save-exit-iwo10009-of-order-iw31-iw32/qaq-p/532403

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/automatic-assignment-of-task-list-to-pm-order/qaq-p/10448147

Best regards, M.

entry.title: Shopify Admin Access Token Limits & Approach to Generate Offline Token via Developer Dashboard
entry.content:
Background
Shopify has introduced limitations on Admin API access tokens at the store level, and at the same time legacy custom apps are being deprecated (no new legacy apps after Jan 1, 2026).

For integrations such as SAP CPI / SAP BTP / SAP Commerce / SAP Concur, we often need a non-expiring (offline) Admin API access token for backend-to-backend communication.

This post explains a parallel and supported approach to generate an offline Admin API access token using the Shopify Developer Dashboard, instead of relying on store-level custom apps.

Why This Approach?

  • Avoids store-level admin token limitations
  • Works with offline access (non-expiring token)
  • Suitable for SAP integrations (CPI, BTP, ECC, S/4HANA, etc.)
  • Uses Shopify Dev Dashboard apps, not legacy custom apps

Step-by-Step: Generate Offline Admin API Access Token

1.Create App in Shopify Developer Dashboard

  1. Log in to the Shopify Developer Dashboard
  2. Create a new app
  3. Select the target store during app setup

2.Configure App Version & Scopes

  1. Navigate to Versions
  2. Create a new version (example: v0.1)
  3. Select all required Admin API Scopes (permissions)
  4. Copy the scopes into Notepad (you‚Äôll need them later)

3.Enable Legacy Install Flow

This is important for offline token generation.

In the version settings:

Set ‚ÄúUse legacy install flow‚Äù = True

4.Set Redirect URL
Under Allowed redirection URL(s), add:

https://localhost/

5.Release the App Version
Click Release

This makes the version active and installable

6. Get Client Credentials
Go to Settings and copy:

Client ID

Client Secret

Generate Admin API Authorization Code
7. Construct Authorization URL
Replace the placeholders with your actual values:

https://{SHOP_NAME}.myshopify.com/admin/oauth/authorize?client_id={CLIENT_ID}&scope={SCOPES}&redirect_uri=https://localhost/&response_type=code


Notes:

{SHOP_NAME} ‚Üí Shopify store name

{CLIENT_ID} ‚Üí From Developer Dashboard

{SCOPES} ‚Üí Paste all scopes copied earlier (comma-separated)


8. Install App & Capture Code
Open the constructed URL in a browser

Click Install

You‚Äôll be redirected to a broken localhost page or redirected page (expected behavior)

In the browser address bar, copy the value after:

code=

Important:

Authorization code expires in 60 seconds

If the page doesn‚Äôt load:

Press Enter once

Immediately copy the full URL

Extract the code parameter


Exchange Code for Offline Admin Access Token
9. Call Shopify Token API (POST)
Endpoint:

https://{STORE_NAME}.myshopify.com/admin/oauth/access_token
Headers:

Content-Type: application/json


Body (JSON):

{
"client_id": "CLIENT_ID_FROM_DEV_DASHBOARD",
"client_secret": "CLIENT_SECRET_FROM_DEV_DASHBOARD",
"code": "CODE_FROM_BROWSER"
}
10. Result
Shopify returns an offline Admin API access token

  • Token does NOT expire
  • Can be safely stored and used in SAP integrations

Now you will have Access token where you can use it in header param (X-Shopify-Access-Token) and graphql API ( https://StoreName.myshopify.com/admin/api/2025-01/graphql.json) and graphql query üôÇ

Key Takeaways

  • Shopify store-level admin tokens now have limitations
  • Legacy custom apps are being phased out
  • Developer Dashboard apps + legacy install flow provide a reliable workaround
  • This method is ideal for SAP CPI / SAP BTP / backend integrations
  • Offline Admin API token is permanent unless revoked

entry.title: Re: SAP BTP - IS - How to become a SAP Integration Suite Consultant beyond SAP CPI - SAP APIM Part I
entry.content: @vinaymittal and @rhviana , I have found both of your blogs useful and created with good intentions. Please remember, it's okay to offer an alternative perspective. But do it without being insulting to one another. . . This is not a good look. I'm sure there is a lot yet to learn from both of you experienced developers, let's not discourage each other from sharing blogs in the future.

entry.title: Re: The Only Script you would ever need for Message Logging and Custom Headers in SAP CI
entry.content:
@vinaymittal

Also, no ‚Äî you didn‚Äôt. This is not a clash of titans or a UFC fight, nor is this an attack against you.
I‚Äôve been active in this space since 2009, and this is the first time I‚Äôve encountered this kind of reaction. I take feedback seriously and always try to extract value from it.

The purpose of my blog series is to help junior, mid-level, and senior practitioners move beyond the narrow ‚ÄúSAP CPI developer‚Äù label and better understand the broader role of an SAP BTP Integration Consultant ‚Äî including how to work across the SAP BTP integration portfolio, either holistically or selectively, depending on the scenario.

The point you raised was already addressed, as it was covered in the very first comment on the blog.

If the intention here is self-promotion rather than meaningful technical discussion, then this exchange no longer adds value.

entry.title: Re: SAP BTP - IS - How to become a SAP Integration Suite Consultant beyond SAP CPI - SAP APIM Part I
entry.content:
@Lyle_H 

Thank you for the reminder and for the balanced perspective.

My intention was never to discourage technical discussion, but to clarify the scope and purpose of the blog series. It is not meant to be deeply technical; rather, it aims to provide guidance for SAP CPI developers to grow beyond this label and better understand the broader role of an SAP BTP Integration Consultant.

I agree that alternative perspectives are valuable when shared respectfully. I appreciate the feedback and fully support keeping the conversation constructive, focused on helping the community learn and grow, and free from unnecessary disrespect or self-promotion.

entry.title: Credit exposure of a blocked document
entry.content:
How is credit exposure of a blocked sales order, delivery document updated?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Credit exposure of a blocked document
entry.content: When the sales or delivery document is created and saved, the credit exposure is updated to reflect the delivery value under the relevant credit exposure category. More detail of the credit exposure category is given in LINK . This ensures accurate tracking of credit limits and exposure within the system.
